SPEECH.PARA: Just to pick up the points made by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), I do concede that this bill represents progress. It represents progress to do away with the 10 per cent rule. What I am suggesting is that further progress can be achieved by doing away with the 20‐student rule. To pick up further the points made by the members for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) and Leichhardt (Mr Entsch), we need to understand, as a parliament, the anomalies that arise from the 20‐student rule. It now means that a school with 21 indigenous students will be eligible for funding, but a like school with 19 indigenous students will not be eligible for funding.

Surely, there cannot be too much difference in running a successful program between a school with 21 students and one with 19. There cannot be a substantial difference in the management and effectiveness of the program on that scale of student numbers.

Further, I acknowledge the point made by the member for Warringah that systemic schools with students less than 20 could still possibly be eligible under the legal advice that has been received by the department for this program funding.

That again raises a further anomaly. Why should a systemic school with 15 indigenous students be eligible for funding, but a non‐systemic school in exactly the same circumstances, facing exactly the same schooling needs, not be eligible for program funding? There are anomalies in this that inevitably arise from bureaucrats and politicians in Canberra setting a cut‐in and a cut‐out point, an arbitrary number that is determined in the national capital for the sorts of judgments and programs that will be run in every single remote school around Australia with a certain number of indigenous students. This is the inevitable problem of cut‐in and cut‐out points being determined in Canberra.

What is wrong with making every single school eligible for this program? Then leave it to the school teachers and administration to work out whether or not they want to take up that eligibility; whether or not they want to apply for this particular source of funding. If it is true, as the members for Robertson and Leichhardt have suggested, that it is just not practical for a school with one or two indigenous students to use this funding effectively, let that be the judgment of the school. Let the school decide that, because of those impracticalities, they do not want to take up the funding for one or two students. But for goodness sake, let the school with 18 or 19 students, where something can be gained, make that judgment for themselves and apply for the funding.

The member for Robertson was saying we are talking about a few dollars. I do not think he could possibly have understood the size of the program. We are talking about funds of up to $3,300 at a remote senior secondary school. That, in anyone's language and understanding of the schooling process, is a substantial amount of money. Particularly when you are talking about remote schooling, $3,300 can make a substantial difference.

We are talking about a substantial program. We are talking about anomalies that have been raised in the system. As for this suggestion of the cost of administration, what is this thing in the bureaucracy that always leads us back to a cost argument? How difficult can it be to notify every single school around Australia that there is a program for schools with indigenous students and, if those schools wish and they deem it practical, they can apply for the funding? They can apply for the funding and then Canberra further down the track can call for a report on the output‐based performance measures and deem whether or not the funding is to be continued. What is this thing that hypnotises parliamentary secretaries and other members of the government based on the judgment of the bureaucracy about cost?

How hard can it be to send a letter to every school to let them know that the program exists; to allow the school to make the judgment as to whether or not in practical terms they wish to apply for funding; to then allow the school to run the program, seek a report about the performance and then decide whether or not the program should continue at that school? That, to me, does not seem to be an overly complex process of public administration. It seems to me to adopt a principle that it is better to have devolution, and better to have the people running schools make the judgment about what is best for the school, instead of having this arbitrary cut‐in and cut‐out point determined by bureaucrats in Canberra.

Whatever we might say across the chamber—Labor versus Liberal—I can tell the honourable members opposite one thing. I am a devolver first and foremost. The centralisation of government in a post‐industrial society has become problematic. Complex equality and complex needs can only be met through devolution of power and judgment to those people who, in good faith, are trying to provide a service for indigenous Australian students. The question of whether or not we can trust the teachers—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated before, I think that there is something in what the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) says. I take his point that, under this legislative process, a school with 21 students is eligible for funding and a school with 19 students, under the proposal as it stands, is not eligible for funding, which, on the face of it, does appear to have something undesirable about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple truth is that we always have to draw lines and sometimes those lines are somewhat arbitrary. If you earn less than $5,000, you do not pay tax. If you earn more than $5,000—or whatever it is—you do start paying tax. If you earn more than $35,000 a year more or less, you lose or start to lose Austudy. We have built into our systems of government and administration all sorts of cut‐off points. It is life! It is life and it is very difficult to get away from them.

The member for Werriwa himself has, I believe, suggested that we should not fund new schools if they do not have more than 50 students. So the member for Werriwa obviously concedes that there are very important circumstances in which we are entitled to make judgments about the viability of programs and institutions. While I accept the, if you like, emotional force of the argument that he has put to us today, I think, when subjected to rigorous scrutiny, the argument looks much less persuasive.

The thing to remember about assistance under this program is that we are not just writing out a cheque and posting it off to the school and forgetting about it. This is a program which is designed to ensure much better monitoring of performance on the ground. This is a program with performance incentives and performance monitoring built in, at every step of the way. It is not just a matter of posting a cheque and forgetting about it or of slipping a cheque under the door and forgetting about it.

We are sending people out to all of these schools to ensure that the Commonwealth money, the taxpayers' money, is actually getting the best possible outcome for the people who need it most—namely, the indigenous students of Australia. It is not just a bucketful of money to be distributed in the same way that the old age pension or block grants to the states, or something like that, is distributed. It is performance oriented and precisely targeted.

If we were to take the member for Werriwa's suggestion to its logical conclusion and have no restrictions whatsoever, we would have every school with any indigenous student applying for this money. As the member for Werriwa has pointed out, there are large amounts of money involved, ranging from $300 to $3,300 for individual students. The problem, if we were to go too far down this track, is that the money would essentially become just another cheque in the mail, and that is not the way to go.

We have had too much of the cheque‐in‐the‐mail approach in the dealings of the Commonwealth government with our Aboriginal Australians. We need to get away from that. We need to get much more focused on ensuring that the Commonwealth's funding does have a beneficial outcome. That is why it is important to have some limitations on how this money is going to be distributed.

Having said all that, I do think there is something in what the member for Werriwa says. As I have indicated before, I will happily take it up with the department to see whether it might not be possible to be a little bit more extensive than we are at the moment. As I said, I think what we are doing is reasonable. I think the member himself has conceded that it is an important step in the right direction. For that reason, I trust that, once we have debated these amendments, which is important, the bill can then pass through this committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of who knows best, I think we need to trust our teachers and our school administrators. The member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) was saying that we need to get away from the approach where you put the cheque in the mail. What is the alternative to the approach of funding schools and allowing teachers and school administrators to get on with the job? The approach that he is advocating is the one that has failed indigenous Australians for decades, where the non‐indigenous bureaucrat jumps out of the helicopter to visit the remote school, clipboard in hand, with a checklist of what he or she thinks needs to be done, without regard to the unique circumstances of that school. I find it one of the most unusual things, in my time as shadow minister for education, visiting universities with layers of administration, listening to parliamentary secretaries saying that we cannot trust teachers and school administrators to run their schools effectively without some non‐indigenous bureaucrat popping out of the helicopter from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely educators in Australia need to be regarded as some of our best educated people, most articulate, most self‐confident, most able to get on with the job; most able to get on with the job if they have the trust of government and if they have the trust of public policy. I could not think of a group of Australians who need less checking, less supervision, less monitoring through the process of delivering a vital, social and public good than our educators at universities, at remote schools—right across the education sector. Surely, if government cannot trust educators to get on with the job of effective education in Australia, our whole system of government is broken. That, to me, is the lasting symptom of what we are doing whenever we devise a new cut‐in or cut‐out point. We are basically admitting that the processes of governance have broken down to the point that these judgments can only be made in a centralised fashion.

The member for Warringah mentioned the question of the establishment of new schools. I think it is commonsense that in establishing new schools there is an element of planning required. The anomalies that have arisen in Victoria where a government school with 50 students closes one week and the next week, a non‐government school with 20 students opens up on exactly the same site with exactly the same buildings, do indicate that at least in the establishment of new schools, we need an element of planning. But beyond the establishment of schools, once they are up and running, surely we can then trust our educators to get on with the job. That seems to be a suitable division of responsibility, if you like, in the running of public administration, and I am advocating that.
Mr Lloyd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You talk about trust. Why not trust our teachers at remote schools to get on with the job? The member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) was saying that just a few dollars are involved. He has now been corrected by the parliamentary secretary. He was saying that it is wasteful to allocate those funds for schools with just a couple of indigenous students. Let the school make that judgment rather than a member from the Central Coast of New South Wales, or the south‐western suburbs of Sydney, or anyone else in this chamber, or anyone else running DEETYA here in Canberra. Let the schools in the remote areas with the indigenous education task at hand make that judgment. I am raising that simple proposition and I think it stands up.

SPEECH.PARA: I am encouraged that the parliamentary secretary sounds sympathetic. He has taken on board my views and says that he will get back to the department. We have been getting back to the department since Adam was a boy and not a lot of progress has been made for indigenous schooling. I suggest that the parliamentary secretary and his colleagues take control of policy, use commonsense in the public interest and make a judgment that these amendments before the parliament are worth supporting, not because we need to get back to the department for the standard advice, but because we have got the commonsense as legislators to recognise their practical application and the sound principles of good governance to devolve away and let the school make the judgment. If they do not want to apply for funds, that is their judgment. If they have got 19 indigenous students and they want to apply for the funding, let them do that and let them get on with the job as well as the school with 21 indigenous students would get on with this particular task.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) is prepared to trust the teachers but, on the basis of the contribution this morning, he is not so prepared to trust the public servants. We, on this side of the House, are happy to trust to the professional judgment of all the various professionals that we are blessed with in this country, whether they be professional administrators, or professional teachers.

SPEECH.PARA: This government trusts the teachers. I personally have an enormous respect for teachers. Apart from the Maker and my parents, my Jesuitical teachers are responsible for whatever I am. So, I have enormous respect for school teachers. A teacher is a combination of psychologist, sports master, academic and, at times, parole officer and parent. It is a remarkable combination of qualities that good teachers have and we in Australia are lucky that we have so many good teachers.

One of the earnests of our trust for the teaching profession is the fact that we are prepared to allow new schools to flourish in this country. I think that it would be easier to take the member for Werriwa as seriously as he wants us to take him—and I do take him seriously—if at the same time he was prepared to say that the ALP would not be arbitrary and set this figure of 50 enrolments when it comes to new schools.

To get to the specifics: if we are to go all the way down the path that the member for Werriwa is suggesting, this particular program would simply become extra block funding for Aboriginal students. It would lose its unique quality. The unique quality, the special value‐adding quality of this program, is that it involves intensive performance monitoring. To have that intensive program monitoring, we have got to have regular visitations from the department with Aboriginal consultants to ensure that the indigenous students at that particular school are getting the improved performance and improved educational outcomes that the taxpayer is entitled to expect for the investment of the dollar. If we were to go down the path advocated by the member for Werriwa inevitably that would be lost. It would be impossible to put that kind of monitoring into schools if they only have one, two or three Aboriginal students.

The fact is that to have a proper indigenous educational program in a school there has to be a certain number of indigenous students. Without that basic number of indigenous students there cannot really be an indigenous‐specific program, so you will lose the ability to actually target your program specifically to the disadvantages that indigenous students face. It is important to retain some kind of core requirement for providing money to schools under this program.

But, as I have said several times now, there is something in what the member for Werriwa says, and I will ask the department to look at it. He was understandably somewhat sceptical about parliamentary secretaries saying that they will look into things. I know we all get the reputation of being mirrors around here, Mr Deputy Speaker, because we are always looking into things. He suggested that people have been doing it since Adam was a boy. Yes, perhaps we have, but yet look at all of the marvellous improvements that the world has experienced since Adam was a boy. Incremental change is what good administration is all about, and incremental change is what we will look at as a result of this debate.
Question unresolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this legislation which does several things. Firstly, it increases the size of the board of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority from three to four. The opposition is quite comfortable with that proposition, which incidentally is in line with our acceptance of the increase in the size of the CASA board, for which legislation finally went through the parliament not so long ago. The bill also clarifies the matter of the appointment of departmental officials to the board, making it an option—but not necessarily mandatory—for the minister to appoint a departmental official to the board of AMSA.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, and most importantly, the bill provides for the merger of the two search and rescue authorities that currently operate within Australia—AMSA and Airservices Australia. This merger was announced some time ago by the minister. The opposition at the time indicated agreement in principle with the proposition, although there are some queries—I will get to them shortly—with respect to some of the things that have gone on in the search and rescue area in recent times. But certainly the logic of a single search and rescue organisation is one that the opposition agrees with. Hopefully, the merger will proceed in as worthwhile a way as possible, with the general efficiency and efficacy of search and rescue operations in Australia enhanced as a result.

Finally, the bill amends the Civil Aviation Act in order to ensure that CASA retains full responsibility for the monitoring and setting of safety standards with respect to particular aspects of search and rescue operations. Again, the opposition has no concerns about that amendment.

I want to make a few brief observations with respect to search and rescue generally. As I indicated in my introductory comments, the opposition has some concerns about recent activities within the search and rescue area that are worth mentioning in the context of this bill, even though, as I have indicated, we support the bill.

The first relates to an incident in December 1995 when a vessel with the name of Red Baron sank off the west coast of Tasmania and one fisherman, Mr Mark Whelan, actually died as a result. There was a search and rescue operation undertaken that involved both Airservices Australia and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The death of Mr Whelan was the subject of a coronial inquiry which reported, from memory, in November of last year or thereabouts.

BREAK.PARA: It was alleged by persons unknown within Airservices that original minutes of the meeting which I think was on 22 December between Airservices and AMSA, and which had been approved by AMSA, were then changed in order to soften implicit criticism of AMSA's role in the search and rescue effort with respect to the Red Baron that ultimately failed to save the life of Mark Whelan.

This issue, in the view of the opposition, remains unresolved. The coroner chose not to directly deal with the matter. It certainly does place some question mark over the operations between the two organisations. It does, of course, indicate that the existence of two separate search and rescue organisations may in fact be seen as a possible cause of this friction or this difficulty. Certainly, if there has been a change in the minutes which is not justified, in order to soften criticism in one of the organisations, that is something that the opposition does have some concern about. As I have indicated, that matter in my view still retains a question mark over it.

To the best of my knowledge the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has not followed through the issue to an outright conclusion. I am not sure who will close the debate, whether it will be the minister or the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson), but I would be interested to hear an update. If the minister's adviser can take that on board, I would be interested to hear whether the minister has taken any further action or reached any conclusive outcome on that question. I do not want to make too much of the issue, but it is of some concern and it is worth pointing to in this debate.

The second issue which has had a far greater public airing in the search and rescue area is the incredible fiasco surrounding the purchase of the PADS equipment which had some significant debate in the parliament earlier this year. I will not labour too much over the detail of that fiasco but it is worth recalling some of the basic detail. Mr Laurence Gruzman, from Search and Rescue Pty Ltd, came and visited the minister early in his term of office—I think it was in April last year—and demonstrated his search and rescue equipment—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the foyer!
—In the foyer of Parliament House, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) reminds me.
—It worked, unfortunately. They found him.

—That is right. The minister was saved, no doubt, from the gigantic waves in the foyer of Parliament House and rescued, and he lived to fight another day. That led the minister to believe that the relevant search and rescue organisations, particularly Airservices, needed to have another look at the PADS system.

BREAK.PARA: There was a subsequent program on 60 Minutes and I think 60 Minutes ought to take stock of their style of journalism because that was a very good example of how grossly biased journalism can actually lead to bad public outcomes. The 60 Minutes program portrayed a bureaucratic organisation for no good reason trying to stop this entrepreneurial Australian with his brilliant new innovation from being able to put that to the use of the nation in rescuing people stranded at sea.

What the program did not mention was that the previous testing of PADS by the RAAF and, indeed, by AMSA had found that even though it was substantially more accurate than the conventional means of dropping life rafts and associated equipment to people stranded at sea, it was not safe for those people dropping it—remembering that this occurs from planes flying as low as 100 feet above what is likely to be fairly turbulent seas.

It was a very, very biased report in that program and it contributed to the climate of opinion that the minister was swept along with. He then gave the go‐ahead to his hand‐picked appointee, the Chairman of Airservices, Mr John Forsyth, to get moving and give PADS a go. What then happened was that at his very first board meeting, without the matter being on the agenda, the chairman of Airservices obtained approval for up to $1 million to be spent acquiring the PADS equipment, subject to a fly‐off test between the PADS equipment and the conventional equipment, which subsequently proceeded and which found that PADS was more accurate. The safety concerns that had previously been found did not surface in this particular fly‐off or were not noticed or not recorded. In any event, Airservices went ahead with the purchase of 104 PADS units.

Incidentally, Airservices went to a training contract with Navair, with a Mr Frank Young, who had been chairman of the evaluation panel in the fly‐off, to train the Airservices personnel in the use of PADS, but without any tender process and with a figure of $4,000 a week involved in the contract. There were numerous rather murky things associated with this whole deal.

In November last year, during the course of training, it was discovered again that for several reasons PADS was unsafe for those using it and therefore training was suspended. Since that time, Airservices have been working away with varying degrees of cooperation from the proponent of PADS, Mr Gruzman, trying to fix the product.

I am advised that in Senate estimates the other day it was indicated that the total cost to the taxpayer, or to the aviation industry through aviation levies which is probably more accurate, of this fiasco is now approaching $1.7 million, and that does not include an estimate for executive time spent in dealing with the issue. That figure includes the purchase of the units themselves, the cost of training, the cost of evaluations, the cost of warehousing and various other things that are occurring.

One of the questions that does not appear to have been addressed is: if the units are finally fixed and they are finally made safe and capable of being used, who ultimately is going to bear the cost of fixing the product? In normal circumstances it would be the supplier, the manufacturer. If you are provided with a defective product then normally you have legal rights to ensure that the manufacturer or the supplier bears the cost of fixing these defects.

So far it does not appear that Airservices have managed to persuade Mr Gruzman that should occur in this case. Clearly, from any rational public policy position, that is precisely what should occur. Legally, Mr Gruzman should be obliged to ensure that the product which he has provided is serviceable or useable for the purpose for which it was presented. It is an old legal concept, a standard legal concept, which still prevails to the best of my knowledge, and it is certainly pertinent in this particular case.

In summary, it is really a cautionary tale for young ministers as to how not to get carried away by exaggerated media hype that presents one side of the story. It is a tale of how not to get carried away by a phobia about pointy headed bureaucrats and Labor Party stooges and the like who are the people who are out to get you.

A minister should assess issues rationally, look back at the history and say, `If the RAAF has tested this thing and has found it to be unsafe, that at least suggests that I had better have a closer look at it before I get too carried away with it. If AMSA has tested it under a former Labor minister and said, "No, don't touch it, it is unsafe for those people using it", then, yes, maybe I had better have another close look at it.' Rather that than say to the chairman of Airservices, `Beauty, let's get in a plane. Let's get the flying cap on and get out there and get the enemy and do some double backflips and loop the loops', which is essentially the approach the minister has taken in this and in a variety of other issues.

Hopefully, he will learn from this fiasco. When he has got some excitable individuals promoting all sorts of interesting things and telling him about the great glories of free enterprise and how the bureaucrats are blocking them and there are all sorts of wonderful opportunities here and it is all a Labor plot, hopefully he will be a little bit more sceptical in the future. Hopefully, he will look closely at what has been going on and what the situation actually is and form a calm judgment about what is in the interests of the Australian aviation industry or the Australian taxpayer and the Australian public in general.

In conclusion, and with those reservations on matters related to the conduct of search and rescue issues by the current minister, in the view of the opposition the bill itself is unexceptional. We would hope that the merger can be completed with the minimum disruption. Mergers of this nature are always problematic for a lot of legitimate reasons, but hopefully this merger can be completed without serious disruption to the very important task of pursuing the search and rescue protection for Australians and ensuring that, for those people who are lost at sea, there is every possibility that they will be saved and looked after and in the quickest possible time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nairn, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This Transport Legislation Amendment (Search and Rescue Service) Bill 1997 is sensible legislation that has allowed the civil maritime and aviation search and rescue coordination functions to be brought together into one national centre. In fact, I attended the opening of the new facility in Canberra recently. The facility, called AusSAR, the Australian Search and Rescue Organisation, was opened by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp). At the opening, the attitude of staff to their coming together into one operation was very positive. The fact that they could talk with the people—with whom they were used to talking on phones, via faxes, and those sorts of things—within the one operation was a great step forward as far as they were concerned. It makes a lot of sense to bring together the two arms of our rescue coordination.

SPEECH.PARA: Having 47 million square kilometres to look after—about one‐ninth of the earth's surface—is a huge responsibility for Australia. Most of that area is ocean. So search and rescue in the ocean will undoubtedly normally involve both sea and air functions. Bringing these together is going to make life a lot easier for people coordinating future search and rescue operations. Good coordination in any rescue operation is absolutely paramount. If the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing, trouble will ultimately eventuate.

Although AusSAR did not have direct involvement in the recent Thredbo tragedy, the rescue operation that took place was an excellent example of the good coordination I just spoke of. Honourable members will remember that I spoke in the House earlier this week about the Thredbo tragedy. I would like to take the opportunity, in speaking to this legislation, to expand on some of those things in relation to the actual rescue operation.

As I said on Monday, there were many rescue services involved in this operation—ambulance services, state emergency services, police, fire brigade, bushfire brigade, plus many more. With so many different services involved, and members of those organisations coming from all over New South Wales and the ACT, as well as other states, it was crucial that the coordination be finetuned, and it was.

I made the comment on Monday that watching them work was inspiring, and I did not say that lightly. The excellent coordination was enhanced by the fact that the rescue workers worked in teams made up of people from each of the main rescue services. Instead of having ambulance people working in one place and emergency service people working in another place, there was a multiservice, multiskilled team working together.

I understand that the services had been training along these lines for some time and the Thredbo tragedy was one of the first situations where this technique could be put in place. It proved to be very successful. Once again, I highlight the contribution made by the police commander in charge of the overall coordination, Charlie Sanderson. It worked quite superbly.

There are two other aspects of the rescue that I also want to highlight—firstly, the quality and competency of the personnel involved and, secondly, the technical aspects. I will deal first with the personnel. I spent a fair bit of time just getting around the site talking to the various people—the ambulance people, the police people, the SES people—and the quality of their work, their experience, the way in which they really put their minds to the job was excellent.

I think we can be very proud of the competency of those people when you consider the harsh conditions that they were actually working in. Probably most members saw plenty of the footage on TV, but it is almost impossible to describe to you just how difficult it was on that site. It seems, in Australia, whether we are talking about search and rescue in the oceans of the Antarctic or a rescue like this, we really can come against some extraordinary circumstances and some extraordinary sites.

Certainly, the Thredbo site was one of those—the steepness of it, the fragility of it. As one of the rescue workers described to me very early on, it was like working on an unset jelly which was at an angle of something like about 60 degrees—and almost 90 degrees vertical in parts. When you think of trying to move your way around that sort of site with enormous slabs of concrete in a virtual card‐deck pattern down that slope, you can get some sort of feel for how difficult it was. If you then throw into that equation, particularly at night, temperatures of minus nine and minus 10, you can appreciate the difficulties of working in those conditions.

Many of the people worked long hours, depending on the role that they were playing in the particular rescue. It may have been only a couple of hours. In certain cases, you just could not have somebody in a position like that for more than a couple of hours at a time. Other people were there for eight, 10 or 12 hours at a time. It was quite amazing.

If I could use one individual as an example of the competency and confidence that was there, it would be an ambulance worker, Paul Featherstone, whose name many would have seen mentioned. He was the ambulance man that was down under the site with Stuart Diver for about 12 hours straight. I met him on the Sunday after they had gotten Stuart Diver out and I did not realise that he was the person who had been down there. My wife and I were talking to him for some time. He was very mild‐mannered and just oozed confidence and competence. It was quite extraordinary. I would not have thought he was the person who had been there because it was the Sunday morning after, and, after what he had been through the day before, I would have thought that he would be taking a couple of days rest but he was back there on the site. It was not until the next day—on the Monday—when I picked up one of the newspapers, which carried a photo of him and mentioned that he was the person, that I realised that he was there. But that is the quality of people we had in that rescue that Australia should be very proud of.

The other aspect I want to raise is the technology involved. We had all sorts of monitoring equipment such as listening devices and heat‐sensing equipment. The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who might be following me, comes from a mining area on the south coast. I think there were people probably from his electorate as well—experts in mining operations—down there giving advice. That technical aspect was very important.

I spent a bit of time with some old colleagues of mine, surveyors who were on the site, watching what they were doing as far as monitoring the site. There were surveyors who came from private firms in Cooma and the coast as well as from Canberra, plus government surveyors, working around the clock, continually watching for any slight movement in any part of the site. If that had occurred, they could have pulled people off because we always had the propensity to lose even more people. The last thing we wanted was rescue workers being among the victims. The use of that technology was quite incredible.

One of the other technology aspects that proved to be very successful was the use of helium filled balloons. These were suspended over the site with halogen lights inside. As soon as it started to get dark, these came on and gave the most superb lighting over the site. It was almost like daylight—very few shadows are created by these lights. Once again, it was technology developed in Australia and probably used for the first time in that type of operation. For future search and rescue it will be a valuable resource.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to the honourable member. Perhaps he could more clearly focus his remarks on the bill. It would be helpful to the House.

—I thought the chair would be reasonably lenient in this regard. I used the example of a search and rescue that required ultimate coordination to be successful. I have highlighted the reasons behind bringing together the maritime and aviation aspects of search and rescue because the whole key to that is coordination. Your timing is fine, Mr Deputy Speaker; I was concluding my remarks on that example. Members on the other side are nodding; I thank them for their indulgence.

SPEECH.PARA: I used the Thredbo tragedy to describe Australia's high level of expertise and management in search and rescue and in our responsibilities for our region. We have further enhanced that through the creation of AusSAR. The member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) mentioned the Red Baron incident. Certainly, that was one of the impetuses for bringing this legislation together. We have had some great successes in search and rescue and not too many failures. Aspects emerging from the Red Baron coronial inquiry certainly accelerated our move to bring these two operations together. AusSAR, to be managed by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, AMSA, will provide an excellent service to our region. We can feel secure in the knowledge that, if any more Raphael Dinellis, Thierry Dubois or Tony Bullimores of the world get into difficulties in our region, a very professional, coordinated operation will be on the job immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to the debate on the Transport Legislation Amendment (Search and Rescue Service) Bill 1997 which is before the main committee. As the shadow minister for transport has already indicated, the opposition supports the establishment of a single national search and rescue organisation. There are few issues in Australia which generate as much interest and emotion as the search and rescue of people who find themselves in distress at sea.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people will remember the miraculous rescue of the British lone sailor Tony Bullimore from his overturned yacht in Antarctic waters. Many people will also recall the rescue of a French woman in similar circumstances some years ago. Most of these rescues cause an enormous amount of controversy, mainly over the huge cost which is involved. But just as we would expect other nations to come to the aid of Australian nationals in distress—and, indeed, under international maritime law it is required—it is also an obligation that we carry to come to the aid of others who find themselves in distress within our area.

If there is one criticism that I agree with in regard to organisation of around‐the‐world yacht races, it is that, instead of having people sail so close to the South Pole, they should sail closer to the Australian coastline. After all, it is Australia that is in the end responsible for the rescue should anything unfortunate come about. More can be done by locals themselves to ensure their safety at sea by making sure that their craft is fully equipped with radio, flares and life jackets. Despite the requirements of this today, many people go out to sea without this important equipment.

It is also important that people understand and respect the elements. I am particularly aware of this, as my electorate has a large coastline, and many people travel to my electorate from western suburbs of Sydney at weekends and holiday periods to put to sea. When they leave western Sydney the weather could be fine, but in a matter of a few hours of travelling time, the seas off Shellharbour and Port Kembla can be whipped up and dangerous. All too often, because these people have travelled so far, they are determined to put to sea, often with disastrous and tragic consequences.

I well remember a few years back it happened that during a search and rescue operation it took several days to locate the boat. They were searching for it off Nowra when, in fact, the boat was found off Newcastle. My information is that after the people in that boat hit the first line of breakers, most of them were dead. The boat was overcrowded and should never have been put to sea.

Australia has accepted responsibility for search and rescue for an area of 47 million square kilometres. This represents approximately 11 per cent of the earth's surface. On anyone's reckoning this is a huge expanse for any search and rescue organisation to monitor.

Until 1 July 1997, the coordination of civil maritime search and rescue services was undertaken by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. AMSA was obliged to perform this function in a manner consistent with Australia's international convention obligations under the Convention for Safety of Life at Sea (1974) and the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue (1979).

Until the same time, the coordination of civil aviation search and rescue services was undertaken by Airservices Australia. AA had obligations to perform this function consistent with obligations under the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation. AMSA performed its coordinating functions from Canberra, while AA operated its functions from Melbourne and Brisbane. A series of amendments to existing legislation in the maritime and aviation areas has already been made to merge civil aviation and maritime search and rescue into one organisation, now to be known as AusSAR within AMSA. This bill puts the merged arrangements operating since June onto a clear legislative footing. The creation of a single search and rescue organisation is a logical and sensible step.

BREAK.PARA: I know that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) announced this in a media release on 15 January 1997. This announcement followed recommendations of a review conducted by an independent consultant into the effectiveness of the government's search and rescue arrangements. Like another consultant's report highlighted last week in the Australian Financial Review, and further revelations in the Senate estimates committee—which is a covert attack plan by the Howard government to seek to smash the Maritime Union of Australia by provoking a confrontation on the waterfront—this consultant's report recommending this merger remains publicly unavailable.

The Minister appears to have a great fondness for consultants' reports. Nearly $90,000 was spent on the government's covert attack plan to smash the MUA, with a further $600,000 to be spent on BCIL Economics Pty Ltd this financial year. But he has much less fondness for making the reports publicly available.

Overall, Australia has a very good and honourable record in its search and rescue capabilities and functions. But recent fiascos in the acquisition of the PADS system has left the record somewhat tarnished, and the shadow minister highlighted the fiasco concerning the PADS. It is interesting that although over $1 million has been spent, this equipment is still in warehouses.

Then, of course, there was the botched handling of the search and rescue operation undertaken by AMSA and AA involving the yacht the Red Baron. This bill in many respects is a result of that fiasco. It is interesting to highlight some aspects of that. On 1 December 1995, Mark Whelan and Stephen Gill left Macquarie Harbour, Tasmania on the Red Baron. This was a fishing vessel with Mr Whelan as the vessel's skipper. Mr Gill owned the vessel but took directions from the skipper. Later that night the vessel began taking on water and both Mr Whelan and Mr Gill abandoned the vessel. One of the men was able to make it to shore, the other died.

This incident has been the subject of numerous commentaries, an investigation and an inquiry. It has also been the subject of intense Senate estimates committee questioning, especially on 10 and 12 June. An executive officer of AMSA, Mr McGrath, told the Senate estimates committee on 12 June that the reality was that the coordination arrangements were inadequate at the time. There was no appropriate mechanism for determining which authority had responsibility. There were problems in the coordination.

As you would appreciate, I am sure, for my sins I read through the Senate estimates committee transcripts concerning these hearings and what became very clear was the utter confusion over which organisation was responsible first for search and rescue for the Red Baron.

My parliamentary Senate colleagues Senator Collins and Senator O'Brien directed some excellent questions to AMSA officials. Hansard records that AMSA was passing the buck to AA, while AA was passing the buck to AMSA. Nobody puts the infuriating nature of this entire buck‐passing into a better context than Senator Collins, when he said:

Airservices said, `It is not our responsibility; it is AMSA's.' Then when you talk to AMSA, AMSA say, `It is not our responsibility; it is Airservices.' Then you get down to splitting hairs about what time of the day it became AMSA's responsibility and so on.
During the Senate estimate's committee hearing on 12 June, Mr McGrath, executive officer of AMSA, said:
All I can say is that, as of 1 July when we take the total responsibility, if we do it again—
referring to the Red Baron incident—
you can kick us harder.

Hopefully, with the passing of this legislation, which, as I have said, the opposition supports, the search and rescue service will operate more effectively, there will be no more room for buck‐passing in the future and no option to avoid responsibility. After all, at the end of the day, there are peoples' lives who depend on it.

We have been very fortunate in Australia not to have a major maritime disaster in our waters. The numerous bulk carriers that went down off the Western Australian coast a couple of years ago—six in a period of 18 months—slid silently to the bottom of the ocean, taking their crews, often from the Third World, with them. We have had no disasters such as they have occasionally had in Europe with the cross‐Channel ferries. I well recall the disaster of the ferry going, from memory, from Latvia to Sweden, which went down off the coast of Finland either last year or the year before. Thankfully, we have had none of these disasters in Australian waters.

We maybe do not have the same standard of ferries. Apart from the ferry to Tasmania, we do not have a great ferry traffic in Australia. With this government's policy of opening up the Australian coastline to the rust buckets of the world, there is the increasing likelihood of that occurring in Australia. Now that the Australian coastline and the lives of the seafarers are at risk it is very important that we have this coordinating service.

Following on from the speech of the honourable member for Eden‐Monaro (Mr Nairn) and linking it to the context of coordination in rescue services, as he so amply did, I would just like to take a minute or so to mention the Thredbo coordination effort in search and rescue. The member for Eden‐Monaro has rightly highlighted the Thredbo tragedy and paid tribute to the work and coordination of the rescue services, which we have all admired. I am very pleased that teams from the Illawarra, both the electorates of Cunningham and Throsby, participated in this work, especially the rescue teams.

As the honourable member for Eden‐Monaro mentioned, it was the mine rescue teams from my electorate and the electorate of my colleague the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) that did such an excellent job in that very difficult and delicate situation. Like the honourable member for Eden‐Monaro, I pay tribute to the work that was done.

I suppose we learn something from every tragedy. I think we did learn something—of course, nothing good can come from a tragedy—about some of this work that has been carried out. Hopefully, it will never happen again.
As we said before, the opposition supports this important legislation now before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McDougall, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport Legislation Amendment (Search and Rescue Service) Bill 1997 being debated here today is about two decades late. That we have managed to pull off some notable search and rescue ventures has been due to the tenacity and the dedication of professionals in the field rather than by good management. This is not to deride the teamwork that has been carried out in Australia by our air and seaborne search and rescue operators; quite the contrary. They do a remarkable job considering the lack of communication between the two separate organisations which make up our national search and rescue unit.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also had the bizarre situation where our search and rescue operations are split into three different headquarters in three different states. This bill enables the government to finally create one national search and rescue body, one organisation that can harness the facilities and expertise which are now shared between Airservices Australia and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. It will also improve the degree of communication between each of these organisations.

A classic example of the lack of coordination and the difficulty under which our men and women in the field have had to work is the fact that our aircraft and our ships at sea do not use the same radio frequency. A classic example of this was in January 1995 when the world watched with bated breath as we searched for lone French sailor Isabelle Autissier. With her yacht dismasted, she was drifting in rough seas between Australia and the Antarctic. To make it even more difficult, the battery on her emergency locating beacon went flat. Miss Autissier was the only woman in that round the world race and that attracted further attention. A Royal Australian Air Force Orion circled above her but could not communicate directly with the ships that were in the area.

That high profile, internationally publicised search and rescue revealed to the world the ridiculous lack of coordination between our air and sea rescue teams. Fortunately, it was successful, but at great cost and risk to those men and women who were out there braving horrendous conditions. The amalgamation of Airservices, run from Melbourne and Brisbane, with the Maritime Safety Authority, run from Canberra, will improve the degree of communication, speed up rescue response times and save more lives.

That our national search and rescue system has been severely hampered by lack of communication has not gone unnoticed by organisations such as Sydney's Cruising Yacht Club. As organiser of the internationally acclaimed blue water classic the Sydney to Hobart yacht race, the club chose to establish its own search and rescue system. They simply installed marine frequency radios in all the helicopters covering the race. As a result, the race organisation has established the best safety net possible and yachts at sea are covered at all times by some form of communication watch. The lack of radio communication is just one classic example of how fragmented our national search and rescue system has been. Often it has been the case of the left hand not knowing what the right hand is doing because they belong to different bodies.

In my lifetime I have seen aircraft control at major airports go from red and green flares—quite literally a puff of smoke—to navigation systems which can guide a pilot from London onto the ground and right to the gate at the Sydney airport. Modern electronic and satellite communication systems quite literally mean that there is no hiding place left in the world. Such a device led the efficient Maritime Safety Authority rescue operators to yachtsman Tony Bullimore eating chocolate bars as he crouched in the dark in his upturned yacht in the Southern Ocean. But radios, mobile telephones, satellite homing devices, lights, whistles and bells are of little value if no‐one can hear them. The situation becomes more tragic when, even if these devices do send out an SOS, there is an argument over which organisation has the job of mounting the rescue operation.

I do not wish to go into a litany of mismanaged search and rescue operations, as too many people have suffered and still suffer because we failed. Suffice to say, there have been some publicly applauded successes but there have been some disastrous and unnecessary failures. Search and rescue cannot be a hit and miss operation, but a coordinated, well‐oiled organisation with strong leadership. And it is not a field for well‐meaning amateurs.

BREAK.PARA: This is the field for aviators, seamen and women, navigators and qualified search and rescue professionals. It also involves men and women with electronic communication skills. This is very much a hands‐on profession, and there is no time for status seekers. Yet both within parliament and the public arena, we have seen years of brawling within our air and sea rescue organisations. We have a situation where the paper shufflers well outnumber the men and women in the field. We have had a situation where those in command of the technical and extremely complex process of ensuring civil aviation safety had never worked in the industry nor, in fact, been involved in any way.

I believe this legislation will resolve many of the problems which have bedevilled both organisations in the past. The skills and knowledge of Airservices Australia and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, combined to form one single organisation, will create a more efficient structure. Ultimately, speed and efficiency are what count in saving lives. For that reason, I give this bill my full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see this legislation before the committee. One should not underestimate the difficulties in amalgamating two organisations that have come together to form AusSAR. It is something that could have happened many years ago but for some of the professional rivalries that existed between the air service sectors and the marine coordination sector. The one thing that must not happen is that those differences that do exist to some extent at the moment not be overcome. They can be overcome. They must be overcome in the interests of marine and aviation search and rescue. The really important people are the people for whom we search and the people who depend upon this unit to provide that search and rescue service.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks through the Australian Maritime Safety Authority annual report for last year at the area that has been covered by Australia, we are responsible under international conventions for 1/9th of the world's surface. That stretches from a point in the north‐west right out towards Cocos Islands—we have carried out rescues beyond Cocos Islands of yachtspersons—and in the north‐east out beyond Fiji, and in the south‐east to a point which, when I look at the map, I cannot even determine a landmass to identify it with because it is so far. The area is 47,000 square kilometres. With a nation like Australia and the resources we have, we have an enormous task in global terms. The rest of the world depends upon us to come to their rescue in the time of crisis.

Now that the satellite systems, Cospas‐Sarsat, are in place and in operation, the area that the satellite passes is the range of Australia just west of Albany to some distance east of Wellington, New Zealand. There is a one‐hour catchment period. In other words, if an EPIRB or an emergency position indicating radio beacon or an emergency location transmitter on an aircraft is triggered, it will be a maximum of one hour before that signal is picked up by a passing satellite. As you go further out, east or west, in all directions from the compass, the time limits go out from one hour to two hours. If it is triggered in Fiji and it is picked up here, it could be up to a maximum of two hours—it does not have to, it will depend on where the satellite is in its transit around the globe—before that signal would be picked up by the passing satellite.

The area goes out at the furthest point, as I mentioned, to beyond the Cocos Islands or to the far south‐east of Australia where the maximum period before the signal would be picked up by the passing satellites would be six hours. On the map shown in the Australian Maritime Safety Authority report, the area is broken up into sections of one hour, two hours, four hours and six hours. So that is the enormous task that we, as a relatively small nation, have in carrying out aviation and marine search and rescue activities.

We also need to understand that there is a clear division of responsibilities. Media make great moment of crisis, of sensationalism, and of search and rescue particularly. There is an expectation, built up because of the success of Australian search and rescue services over the years, that if you are missing, you must be found; not that if you are missing, you may be found. The expectation that has built up in the minds of many people, certainly in the minds of many of the media, is that if somebody is missing, they must be found, otherwise the service is deficient. It does not necessarily follow that if you are missing, you are going to be found. Australia, through its professionalism and the range of assets and equipment available, will do its absolute best to ensure that you are found and successfully rescued.

But the key to all of this, the starting point, is the preparedness of the persons themselves. If people go down to the sea in small boats that are overloaded, underfuelled and not carrying radios, not having submitted a plan or told somebody where they are going and when they expect to return and not having checked on the weather conditions to ensure that the journey they want to undertake can be undertaken safely in those weather conditions, then they are going to have a problem and their loved ones will have a problem. When they go missing it will not be the fault of the searchers or the rescuers, it will be the fault of a lack of preparedness. Preparedness on the part of the voyager is priority one. Then we come in with the professionalism of Australia's services.

We need to remember always, in all of the sensationalism that attaches to some of these magnificent rescues and searches, that the searchers and rescuers put their own lives on the line almost all of the time. Their lives are at risk. In the search to locate the missing person, we have to bear in mind the dangers that are imposed upon the people carrying out the actual search and later the rescue.

We should also remember that the area of jurisdiction is very clear. Territorial seas and inland waters are the responsibility of the state authority. Beyond the territorial sea limit, it is the responsibility of the federal government. We pick up that responsibility as a nation through the international maritime conventions to which we subscribe. I referred to that earlier. If we look at what is shore based, in respect of hikers, land vehicles, all pleasure craft and fishing vessels at sea, responsibility begins with the police. At any point in an area of state jurisdiction, the state authority can turn to the federal authority—now AusSAR—and ask them to accept responsibility for the further conduct of the search and of the rescue. That happens quite frequently.

In respect of defence aircraft, it is the responsibility of the RAAF. In respect of vessels other than those for which police and defence forces are responsible, it is the responsibility of AMSA. In respect of Royal Australian Navy ships and submarines and all Australian Defence Force shipborne naval aircraft, it is the responsibility, in the primary instance, of the Royal Australian Navy. But there is a tremendous amount of teamwork that goes on across those agencies. The system could not function without that teamwork.

I want to mention the magnificent rescues of the French and British yachtsmen in January this year, 2,600 nautical miles south‐west of Western Australia, at the absolute limit of our capacity in terms of the equipment that was available, and in weather conditions that were extreme and that we rarely ever see close to our coastline. I want to pay tribute to everyone that was associated with the rescue of those round the world yacht race crew members. They were the Britisher Tony Bullimore and the Frenchmen Raphael Dinelli and Terry Dubois.

I had the pleasure a couple of years ago in Newcastle of meeting the French yachtswoman that we rescued in 1994. That was a successful search and rescue and it was pilloried in some quarters because of the expense. But people who make those kinds of comments, particularly journalists, have very short memories. We are party to international conventions, we accept those responsibilities, and we expect, as Australians, that other parties to those international conventions will similarly come to the assistance of Australians when they are in distress.

I call to mind the case of the Rockin' Robin—the yacht off the north‐east of Australia in which four Australians perished. Those people came from just south of Newcastle, south of Lake Macquarie. There was a great deal of publicity about it and a great deal of criticism about weather conditions and what kinds of rafts could have been dropped, but it does not help anybody to rake over those memories other than to express our deepest sympathy for the families of the four persons who were lost.

What was conveniently forgotten was that, at that time, the French navy sent a frigate from Noumea right out almost to the boundary of their area of responsibility. There were French aircraft involved in the search for and location of those people. Where the tragedy occurred was in the weather conditions and in the dropping of equipment to those people. It is a two‐way process. It is all very well to make comments about what Australia expends. I would ask people who make those comments to think about the ignominy and the abuse that would have been heaped upon Australia internationally had we followed the advice of some people back in January who said, `Bad luck, it is a private yacht race. They are on their Pat Malone. We are not going to spend taxpayers' dollars in doing anything about their rescue.' That did not happen. What happened is that young Australians from the Marine Rescue Coordination Centre—as it was known then and now AusSAR—the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force achieved a level of performance which is unsurpassed in rescue and search at sea.

Their performance demonstrated to the rest of the world in a way that it could not otherwise be demonstrated that Australian trained aviators and Australian trained mariners are of world class—we are absolutely world class. That is why they are in demand as airline pilots around the world; that is why our officers are in demand on ships around the world. If it is a difficult task you call for an Australian; if it is a complex task you call for an Australian. In those rescues we proved not only our support for those conventions that we subscribe to but we showed the rest of the world just how well Australians are able to perform as individuals—their professionalism, their competence—and how well we are able to perform as a team.

The world watched almost in awe as the Australian teamwork of our defence personnel and Marine Rescue Coordination Centre civil personnel carried out those magnificent rescues at the cutting edge of technology and at the extreme geographical limits of Australia's rescue capacity. Their professionalism illustrated Australia's competence in marine and aviation search and rescue skills.

As I said earlier, not every search results in locating the missing person and not every rescue attempt is successful. The prime factor is the preparedness of those who want to go to sea or those who fly. It was very clear in this case that the preparedness of the yachtspeople themselves was a major factor in their survival. Had they not had the gear that they were wearing and had they not had the radio and equipment to help locate them, then they would have simply been casualties. That is often overlooked by what I refer to as vested interests and often by some individuals in the media.

Let me contrast the other side of it for you, Mr Deputy Speaker. If one of those RAAF Neptune aircraft had gone in with its crew of 10, then the much lauded success in rescuing Tony Bullimore—to which I have been referring in the last instance—would have become blazing headlines. It would have been referred to as an unmitigated disaster and unmitigated incompetence in even attempting the rescue.

In this area of search and rescue, looking at the annual report of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, I note that, whilst the growing usage of distress beacons shows an improvement in the success rate in search and rescue techniques, there has also been an increase in false distress alerts or in undetermined causes of beacon alerts. In fact, in 1995‐96, 96.4 per cent of distress alerts were undetermined or false. In some cases, particularly on small boats, the EPIRBs go off by somebody bumping them or flicking them on to see whether they work. That triggers off the whole process in Canberra and sets in operation the AusSAR centre. An enormous expense is generated because of that.

In 1995‐96, there were some 6,608 search and rescue incidents, of which 79 led to search activity. That was an increase of 21.5 per cent over 1994‐95. They resulted in the rescue of 108 people, and that was a decrease of 25 per cent on the previous year. The best year would be when no search was necessary. That would mean proper preparedness: if people took proper account of weather and maintained proper communication, they would not have the unfortunate problem of finding themselves in crisis.

Looking through the search and rescue performance statistics, we can see the changes that have taken place in performance and effectiveness. Looking at the dollar amounts, the number of persons rescued and the effectiveness of the rescue in a reporting period, in 1991‐92, the amount is $119 rising, in 1996‐97, to $138. If we look under EPIRB usage, the total number of searches resulting from EPIRB alerts fell from 70 per cent to 66 per cent between 1991‐92 and 1996‐97. The total number of searches resolved was 97.65 per cent. Switching to the next column, the total search duration cost for aircraft under EPIRBs is $350.72. This is analysed in all those documents in the performance figures of the organisation and the effectiveness of the search. As I said, the best search is when no search is necessary.

I am very pleased that this legislation is before us. I am pleased that the two organisations have been brought together. In the past, the aviation rescue coordination centres in Brisbane and Melbourne have always been involved. The actual coordination of all the elements was done by what was then the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, but now AusSAR. They determine the search area. They work out the grid. They take account of sea currents, weather conditions and times—all of the factors involved. If members have not had a chance, they ought to look at that centre and its databases in operation. They are absolutely world class.

They take account of all that information. They determine the grid areas to be searched. They then use it to task the aviation rescue coordination centres to arrange the aircraft. It is passed over to the aviation rescue coordination centre. They task the aircraft, be they civil or defence, on the grids and the frequency to be searched. In this operation, all the officers are together in one room—some people are at one end; some are at the other end. This will produce a much better quality search and rescue service for people who need help in times of crisis. It is going to save money but, most importantly, we will have a better service.

BREAK.PARA: Supplementing that is a network of civil search and rescue units. There are in excess of 30 of those; I have one in my own electorate, Aeropelican at Belmont. At each of those units there are civilians trained in aerial search and rescue and drops, and stores of equipment are maintained there. There are rafts and beacons, all the equipment that is necessary. All that equipment is located at the airport. The people are trained regularly and they attend refresher courses.

When a crisis occurs, when now AusSAR calls on a search to be carried out, at those 30‐plus centres around Australia the stocks of equipment are ready, there are people with the right skills ready to participate in the search, and all that will now be controlled out of one room. It makes good sense. It is going to be a more efficient service, but most of all it is going to improve further the capacity of the centre to carry out a successful search and rescue operation. To those who depend upon this service, they will know that these searchers can give their very best and take the greatest risks that are reasonable.

However, at the end of the day the most important factor is the preparedness of the person who goes to sea or hops on an aircraft that may or may not be airworthy, or that may or may not have sufficient fuel on board. Those people who generate the problem in the first instance, those people who effectively are putting their lives and the lives of their passengers at risk, should spare a thought for the dangers that are then created for the searchers and the rescuers. I am pleased to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in speaking briefly to the Transport Legislation Amendment (Search and Rescue Service) Bill which amends the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act, the Air Services Act and the Civil Aviation Act, I endorse the closing remarks of the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) in highlighting the fact that those people who go to sea, those people that fly aeroplanes, have a responsibility to ensure that they take the necessary precautions, just as it is the responsibility of the authorities that surveil those aircraft and those ships to ensure that they maintain seaworthy and airworthy craft.

SPEECH.PARA: When you look at the area that Australia has responsibility for in terms of search and rescue, it is absolutely enormous. I saw a figure of about 47 million square kilometres, or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 47,000 million square kilometres.

—It is an enormous area that we have responsibility for. As the previous speaker indicated, the actions of the search and rescue authorities in Australia have shown the world that we are one of the best nations in the world as far as search and rescue are concerned, with our pilots and our navigators at sea, particularly when you look at the enormous expanse of the Southern Ocean between Australia and Antarctica that we have to look after.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill emanates from a review that was initiated by this government last year to look at the costs and benefits that might arise from a rationalisation of the Commonwealth's civil maritime and aviation search and rescue functions into one national coordination centre. The current coordination functions are split between state and territory police services, industry and volunteers. Someone earlier on indicated that that worked very well in the recent disaster in Thredbo as far as the coordination of emergency services went in that specific location and that sort of emergency, but search and rescue at sea, and particularly in the region that is being covered, requires better coordination than that.

The recommendation from the review of the previous arrangements was that a single coordination centre for search and rescue be established and managed by AMSA. That is what this bill is all about. It is good to see that it is getting support from the opposition, which is one of the positive elements of proceedings in this parliament that we see more often than a lot of people out there in the real world realise.

The establishment costs for AusSAR are interesting in that budget funding of $16.6 million is provided to AMSA in 1997‐98, the majority of which is for the costs of civil search and rescue capability. AMSA's costs of establishing AusSAR would be estimated at between $4 million to $5 million, so it has been budgeted for.

There are clearly defined benefits which will accrue from the amalgamation of these services. It will facilitate the development of a national strategic overview of civil search and rescue. It will facilitate consistency in operational procedures, integration of program priorities and investment decisions, common standards of practice and training, and national‐international consultative processes.

A great deal of research has gone on prior to the drafting of this bill to establish this new service. I know that the previous speaker alluded to the rescue that took place in the Southern Ocean of the yachtsmen involved in that round the world race. There was a great deal of public comment across Australia as to what Australia's responsibilities are, what they should be and should we be spending a lot of taxpayers' dollars with regard to search and rescue involving foreign nationals.

It is important to note that, as a nation, we are signatories to a number of international conventions that require our involvement in these operations. Certainly, the responsibility fell on Australia at the time to conduct the search and rescue operation for those people. I am sure they appreciated it. I think I saw in the media recently that the Englishman, Tony Bullimore, is back at sea in another single‐handed race at the moment. As the previous speaker did indicate, those people in that race certainly took all precautions as far as the seaworthiness of their craft and the safety equipment that they had on board were concerned, because those precautions kept them alive until the Australian search and rescue organisations could complete the task.

We are bound under international conventions and have an obligation to provide search and rescue services for seafarers in an area that covers about 11 per cent of the world's surface. I suppose that is just a result of where we are located in the Southern Hemisphere, as a very large island continent in the Southern Ocean. As I mentioned, it is interesting that we are responsible for maintaining search and rescue operations over 11 per cent of the world's surface.

I also made mention of the responsibility of surveillance authorities and what should be done to ensure that ships and ocean‐going vessels are seaworthy and that aircraft are airworthy. It is interesting to note what the government is doing with regard to substandard shipping. It has been the government's policy to ensure that the highest standards of safety are maintained in shipping in Australian ports and waters. To reduce the use of substandard shipping in Australian waters, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority undertakes rigorous port state control inspections of foreign ships visiting Australian ports. AMSA's inspection rates have steadily increased. In 1996 nearly 60 per cent of eligible ships—that is, those not inspected by AMSA during the previous six months, or three months for passenger ships—were inspected compared with 55 per cent in 1995. Port state control is proving to be an effective means of combating the use of substandard shipping. In 1996, the average detention rate of vessels fell to 8.5 per cent from 9.6 per cent in 1995.

BREAK.PARA: In line with the recommendations of the Ships of shame report to increase the effectiveness of port state control, AMSA publishes a monthly report showing details of ships detained, including information on the ship's owner, manager and charterer. It is important to note, and it has been noted by a number of contributors to this debate, that it is incumbent not only upon the operators of these vessels but also the surveillance authority—I am sure that it will be in the future an increasing effort by government—to maintain a decent standard not only of Australian shipping but also shipping that enters Australian ports. Ultimately, if we do not, it is going to impact on those search and rescue facilities that we are debating today about providing under this new act.

In closing, I just want to add my support to the bill. It is a move forward. We are going to be engaging new technology as far as the contractual arrangements that are in place for using facilities with Telstra in the future. I think that it is a positive move and one that is an indication to our international neighbours that we are very committed to moving forward and providing a very good service as far as civil search and rescue operations are concerned in that 11 per cent of the world's surface that we have responsibility for.

Nonetheless, I thank the opposition for their support of this bill and I think the country will be a far better place for the implementation of the legislation.
