SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is a pretty short bill by our standards. It is only 10 pages long and it is uncontroversial. It is legislation which the Labor Party opposition will be supporting because it tightens up some aspects of Medicare to do with pathology.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will do a number of things. Firstly, it will allow backdated accreditation approvals for pathology operators, thereby avoiding problems with Medicare benefits eligibility due to administrative delays.

Secondly, it will increase the penalty for pathology collection centres that do not display the accreditation notice. Thirdly, it will tighten the requirements in relation to pathologists renting space from referring doctors to reduce the possibility of kickbacks. Fourthly, it will allow the Health Insurance Commission to impose penalties for minor infringements.

The bill builds on last year's reform package in which the government and the Australian pathology profession struck a deal to control costs. Last year's deal itself built on the former Labor government's initiatives to control pathology expenditure, and that deal has our support. The fact that another agreement has been reached and another deal done to ensure that inappropriate practices are stamped out, also has the support of the opposition.

BREAK.PARA: In many ways, this bill highlights the difference though between constructive reforms to Medicare, which I am delighted to see in this bill, and the sort of negative attacks on Medicare which unfortunately have been made far more common under this government. We have seen a freeze on Medicare rebates in 1996; a 10 per cent cut for certain high cost procedures, including eye and knee surgery; a 10 per cent cut to families who need to use IVF services, and a 50 per cent cut to certain psychiatry rebates. We have seen the closure of 43 Medicare offices throughout the country, making it harder for people to claim their Medicare rebates.

Finally, we saw the government seeking a massive $700 million cutback in last year's budget and an effort to introduce a system of therapeutic group premiums in a manner that bypassed the parliament by way of regulation which was not disallowable in the Senate.

The opposition is also pleased to see that the measures that are contained in the bill have been agreed with the pathology profession. Unfortunately, this is also in contrast with most of the negotiations conducted by the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), who seems to have a singular talent for failed negotiations—with the medical profession, his state counterparts, and even his cabinet colleagues.

This is not a point I make lightly. Health policy is always a complex and difficult area. There are always at least three sides to most arguments in health. Sid Sax aptly described the health policy world a few years ago as a strife of interests. Therefore it is doubly important that a health minister be open and consultative, and have the personal skills to negotiate, because that is the only way that progress can be made.

This government seeks to rule by decree, and their petulance at having to consult is plain for everyone to see. If this is to be a government that contributes anything positive in health, if we are to see any constructive gains, the government and the minister must learn to work with other interests in our society and with the other stakeholders in health.

As I said, Madam Deputy Speaker, the opposition is prepared to support these amendments, which are uncontroversial. We will seek to ensure that the public interest is protected in services provided by pathologists in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997 has been prompted by the successful negotiation of a three‐year agreement between the Commonwealth government and the pathology industry. The essence of the agreement, which commenced on 1 July 1996, is to cap expenditure for pathology on the Medicare benefits scheme and keep it to predetermined amounts over the 1996‐97 and 1998‐99 periods.

SPEECH.PARA: The cap for expenditure was set at six per cent; and last year, for the first time, pathology was able to keep Medicare benefits growth below six per cent. As a consequence, pathology providers were able to gain another six per cent rise in Medicare benefits. The industry has become self‐regulatory, and because of the agreement the government now knows what growth will be. Growth in costs in 1996‐97 was significantly lower than under the previous government. The industry is using innovative solutions which introduce new procedures, and they in turn save on costs. The savings thus made will release funds for other programs, such as our immunisation and mental health programs.

The profession is also working with the Health Insurance Commission to look at ways to target inappropriate practices. The bill seeks to strengthen the power of the Health Insurance Commission to enforce the provisions of the act relating to pathology. It strengthens a provision relating to the licensing scheme for pathology specimen collection centres to ensure that a notice establishing that the centre is licensed is clearly visible, thus deterring the operation of unlicensed centres. Licensed centres now have to display their licence number, so pathology laboratory providers know that their competitors are operating licensed premises.

Giving the Commonwealth, through the Health Insurance Commission, the power to prescribe penalties for minor pathology offences in regulations will assist enforcement of regulations. The Australian Association of Pathology Practitioners thinks that is a great idea. At present, the Health Insurance Commission has to go through the court system under criminal law, and it is almost impossible to collect evidence suitable for a criminal court. Infringements will now be dealt with as civil actions, and the Health Insurance Commission will be able to impose penalties.

The pathology industry in Australia on the whole is very well regarded throughout the world. We have a national accreditation scheme, a good level of quality and very uniform standards across the nation. Because of these high standards it is necessary to make sure that the few people who do not comply with the regulations are brought to accountability.

The bill also seeks to strengthen the provisions of the act to clearly prevent an approved pathology practitioner entering into arrangements whereby inducements or kickbacks are provided to a medical practitioner or entrepreneur. It removes any ambiguity in a current provision relating to the occupation by a pathology company of premises owned by a medical practitioner or entrepreneur.

An example of an arrangement which the bill seeks to deter is one where an approved pathology practitioner enters into an arrangement with a medical practitioner or entrepreneur for the use or occupation of premises, but merely oversees the use of premises through agents or employees and provides kickbacks to the medical practitioner or entrepreneur by way of rent.
However, the exercise is not to make it harder for patients to access a collection centre. In many ways this will provide more service centres, better services and reduced costs.

The amendment to allow for the payment of Medicare benefits in some circumstances for services provided by a pathology provider who is out of date was agreed upon by the Australian Association of Pathology Practitioners. Pathology has very regulated laboratories and the laboratories have to register every 12 months. Sometimes the paperwork does not reach its destination in the right time frame. This will also protect against the Health Insurance Commission and the health department which may on occasions miss processing an application. This amendment allows for these possibilities.

The laboratories will have up to one month to gain application approval. However, the minister must be satisfied that it is in the public interest to backdate that approval. For example, bills from one pathology laboratory were signed off by a resident pathologist. However, it was realised that he, being new to the position, had not yet been recognised by the Health Insurance Commission. This could have had a dramatic effect on the pathology company, who would not have been eligible for Medicare benefits, and for the patients, who would not have received their rebate. The problem was quickly rectified, however. But, under this amendment, these hiccups can be dealt with comfortably.

The Australian Association of Pathology Practitioners is very supportive of the amendment. It has been discussed at length by the Pathology Consultative Committee. Many challenges within the industry are being identified and the cooperative efforts of the concerned committees are shown in this bill. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In this bill, we address a number of challenges which the Medicare and health systems have faced in Australia for some time. The challenges include issues such as medical fraud and overservicing and questions of how we contain the costs of the Medicare system and, indeed, the health bill of the nation as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: These are issues that are very serious. They have been around for many years. They require us to think about ways and means in which we as a nation can bring the health bill under control but provide the services which the people of the nation need for good health.

We need to begin with the premise that good health is a fundamental right that people have in a democratic and civilised society. We also need to accept the fact that in Australia we have finally come to a bipartisan position that we believe in universal health care.

Given those two principles—the right to basic health and a belief in universal health care—we then have to look at ways and means of delivering that universal health care while containing the costs to a reasonable level. That is not easy. In a whole range of areas, we have had problems. This bill deals with some of the most complex issues that we have had.

For example, on the one hand you want to be able to provide the services to everyone who needs them. On the other hand, you have the problem of the pressure for overservicing and even for fraudulent practice. Some people feel that the medical professions should not only be a guarantee of a good living, but should be a guarantee of an exorbitant living. In that situation you can easily get to the point where services are very costly. There is overservicing and there can be a situation of connivance and collusion between certain practitioners and the providers of subsidiary services, such as pathology.

It is in that context that we have this bill. In general, we support the thrust of the bill. But I want to make the observation that these matters are not going to be dealt with just simply by legislation, just simply by saying, `Here are some rules, here are some regulations. We are going to give the HIC significantly increased powers,' as this bill does, `to be able to check things, to be able to ban certain activities, to be able to put into place measures to deal with excesses on the part of providers of pathology services.' All of those things are there, and they are welcome.

But I do not believe that we will really get to the heart of the problem until we start to focus again the attention of the nation on what the real meaning of medical practice is and what the real meaning of the provision of these services is. These services are there for those people who need them. They are not there for people to exploit them to make money unnecessarily. Unfortunately, there are people in the community who keep doing this with the medical profession and with these subsidiary services, and we do need to deal with that problem.

When I was first elected to parliament years ago—sometimes too many years ago—I recall that I was on the Public Accounts Committee. Its major inquiry at that time was an inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing—a massive inquiry, a huge issue and big reports. Finally the government did something about it—this was in the last term of the Fraser government—and when we came into government later we also took it up and we put into place a number of measures. But it appears that the more measures you put into place, the more you find that, a bit like the taxation system, there are ways and means of getting around the measures. For example, this bill refers to certain activities by some pathologists where there is a form of kick‐backs to practitioners by having shared offices or other shared facilities and privileges, therefore getting around what might be called the `blunt' bribe but actually having an indirect impact in terms of an incentive for particular services to be proceeded with.

BREAK.PARA: I said there needs to be a change in our culture. There are certain elements that are required for that. The first is that we need a lot more public appreciation of the great work which the bulk of medical practitioners do, especially those involved in very difficult work in the hospitals, public and private, where a lot of hard decisions have to be made about operations and about the right way to go ahead in a difficult case. I do not think we sufficiently appreciate the dilemmas which doctors have and the hard decisions that they have to make, especially in these situations. So it is very important that the public starts to appreciate medical practitioners more than we have in recent times.

There was a time when to be a doctor was probably the highest occupation in the land. That is no longer the case. That is partly to do with some of these bad doctors, but it is also partly to do with a general cynicism in the society about public service, about service to the community, where the only sign of status and respect in the community increasingly becomes how many dollars you have rather than what contribution you are making to the community. If the medical profession falls for that situation, where individual doctors and specialists seek to gain status not on the basis of their contribution to the community, but on the basis of their income and of keeping up with the Joneses on very high incomes, then we are going to get into an incredible problem in this country in terms of medical practice and the costs of health. So the government and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), who I know is always well‐meaning, should be looking at a program of greater recognition of the good work of doctors and specialists.

With respect to those carrying out the specialised services, I noticed that there has been some problem about those who are licensed and those who are not licensed. Perhaps the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) can explain it to me. I do not understand why unlicensed people should be in this area at all. Why don't we have a more competitive system of licensing and have everybody licensed? If you are not licensed, you just do not do it. I would like to know what the answer is to that question from the minister and perhaps it could be taken on board to do something about that.

Even with the licensed and approved pathology authorities, we obviously need a situation in which we control the cost of this. Of course, there are difficult questions. You cannot say to a doctor, `Only these tests are necessary and those ones are not.' But there is no doubt that there has been some conniving in this area, where people have had unnecessary tests and where, unfortunately, in some cases, individual doctors have received inducements and incentives to have those tests. I believe we have to do something more to tackle that issue.

This is not to say that I do not agree with the provisions of the bill. I think the bill goes some way towards achieving that. But, as I said, you do not just tackle it by law enforcement. You also tackle it by creating a different atmosphere and a different spirit in terms of the socio‐cultural rewards for people in the medical professions, including pathologists, in relation to what they are doing. If the community can get a greater cognisance of that and if the government can encourage that, then I think we will have less propensity for these actions to occur.

Maybe I am being a bit idealistic here, but I do think that we can try and encourage in our society, not only in this area of medicine but in other areas, a greater sense of community and public contribution. We need society to recognise that a lot more than they have done to this point.

I support the bill. I hope that the measures will deter those who are determined to proceed in ways which are against the law or the spirit of the law. Hopefully, this occasion will provide for us the opportunity to encourage those who are acting in a positive way so that others may join them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak specifically to the Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997, I would like to pick up on a couple of the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). I was very pleased to hear him quite rightly speak of the very good and very capable work done by the vast majority of medical practitioners. Within any group of individuals within society, whether it be medical practitioners or members of parliament, there will be a section who will bring only shame to themselves and the profession within which they work.

SPEECH.PARA: He also spoke about the regard in which doctors had previously been held and asked why it had declined. It is certainly one of the questions that I have grappled with myself in recent years. I feel that obviously our society has changed in many enormous ways. Many Australians—and I would suggest many who support the views of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), for example—do not quite understand these changes. They are grieving about changes that they have seen in their country and their world. They are also angry about quite a few of them.

Whether it be people in science, in higher education, in medicine, the law or other professions, we all stand accused of changes that have been brought upon society over which many people feel they have no control. Of course, George Bernard Shaw in the 19th century was bemoaning the medical profession. I do not think a lot has changed in that regard, but many Australians assign blame to professional, scientific, engineering and other people for the kinds of things that they have seen happen in their country.

I do not always agree with the member for Calwell but he was quite right when he said that what we really need to be doing is rediscovering a sense of community, whether it is the medical profession or anything else. In fact, in terms of addressing the phenomenon of the member for Oxley and her supporters, I feel it is important to remind ourselves that what we need most in this age of economic and technological uncertainty is the resource of our personal relationships; what we need most is to build a sense of community; what we need most is one another.

Some of the behaviour which this bill seeks to address is but a symptom of a society that is failing. Historically, if you look at societies that get into trouble they are ones that develop a preoccupation with death, whether it is in the form of suicide—Australia, of course, has the highest youth suicide rate in the OECD—or death in the form of euthanasia. We have gambling elevated to the status of religion in some parts of Australia. We also are a country that is dividing along racial lines. We have a preponderance of drug use which has reached epidemic proportions. We are not alone in this regard. But, historically, societies like that are the ones that get into trouble.

One of the things that has upset me in the last decade—and my foray into medical politics was initiated by the former member for Canning, Mr George Gear, who sought to build a career for himself in the denigration of my profession—is that when people seek to denigrate or bring down to the lowest common denominator institutions or things in which we really ought to have some confidence or to tear apart our mesh of values, it is actually the people who most benefit from them who suffer most. I really question whether we are a better society today because people have a lower regard for God, king and country, professions, doctors and all the rest of it.

The Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997 gives effect to a number of government initiatives which relate to Medicare benefits for pathology services. It will allow the Governor‐General in Council to make regulations to give the Health Insurance Commission the power to impose penalties for less serious infringements that relate to pathology. What we are really looking at is a series of infringement notices or penalty notices, a bit like traffic infringement notices, or expiation notices, for example, in the ACT for cannabis users, and so on. Where an approved pathology service has failed to inform the public that a pathology laboratory is no longer approved and that services it is providing are not attracting a Medicare benefit, under these provisions it will be possible for the commission to simply issue a fine to that pathology provider.

The member for Calwell asked a question in passing about licensing centres, asking himself why there would be people who are out there providing services who are unlicensed. Why do people do anything that contravenes the law? Why do they speed in cars? Why do they drink and drive? Why do they not wear seatbelts? In fact it was the previous government, to its credit, that through negotiations with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices, the AMA and the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia developed a licensing system to control the number of outlets to which patients could go to have their blood and other samples taken. The reason for doing that was that we had had a profligate expansion of the number of places to which people could go and get pathology.

You often find in medicine—and pathology is certainly no exception to this—that demand is often determined by supply. The more doctors you can provide in a particular area or the more pathology services you can provide, the more the number of services will be demanded and will be consumed. So that was a genuine attempt to try and limit the number of outlets that were providing pathology services.

It was also intended to improve the quality of some of these outlets and also to have some regard to geographic distribution and the convenience of patients. However, we ended up having, at one stage, more pathology collection centres than we had Chinese restaurants in some parts of Australia.

The bill makes an amendment also to the licensing scheme for the collection of pathology specimens and it introduces a requirement that the owner of a licensed collection centre needs, all the time, to display a sign which is visible, is factual, from the outside of the building to let the public know that this centre is licensed, because if you go to an unlicensed centre and you have a specimen taken, those services will not attract a Medicare benefit.

The bill increases the maximum penalty for infringement from $100 to $1,000. The intention is to provide a deterrent to the operation of unlicensed collection centres and protect consumer interests. I became aware of a case recently involving a Sydney pathology company that had had a licensed collection centre which had then become delicensed. Patients had continued to attend this particular centre, had had their specimens taken and then, much to their horror they discovered that there was no Medicare benefit being paid for the services that they had consumed.

Currently, the act restricts pathology providers from going into arrangements for the occupation of premises with medical practitioners or entrepreneurs, except for the establishment of a licensed collection centre. The aim of this is to prevent arrangements that really stop inducements to medical practitioners.

In my previous life I certainly became aware of instances where general practitioners, for example, would be referring all of their pathology to a certain pathology provider. They would then, for some inexplicable reason, switch to another pathology provider and the amount of pathology that they were providing increased fivefold. However, once they had received a visit from the Health Insurance Commission they then, for some equally inexplicable reason, would reduce their pathology ordering by fivefold.

In other words, there have been arrangements, and I believe to this day there continue to be arrangements, where certain pathology providers have paid a very, very generous rent for what is basically a broom cupboard, or in some cases the bottom draw of a desk. The general practitioner, usually a GP, has a very powerful financial incentive to ensure that the patients are ordered pathology only from this particular pathology provider, and indeed a lot of it.

The member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), and I did not hear previous speakers on the other side but I can imagine what they said, was also focussing quite rightly on the volume of services that are being ordered.

I agreed with the former member for Blaxland, Mr Keating, even less than I have agreed with the member for Calwell, but when he was the Treasurer in 1990, Mr Keating, in announcing the pharmaceutical benefits copayment—a foreign concept for the Australian Labor Party but it involved people actually paying something for a service that they received—in defending this measure, said that anything that is free leads to overuse. I have found, whether it has been in pathology or whether it has been in other areas of medical practice, that it is very unusual for a person to have services provided to them which are not necessary if they are paying something for that service.

Our government, like the previous government, remains tethered to and very committed to the current Medicare arrangements, but as Australians who like to rise above ideological posturing we need to accept that if you give Australians a credit card, if you encourage them to go and use it and the government will underwrite it, we should not then be surprised when we then find that the suppliers of services, at least some of them, feel that they can abuse the privilege that has been given to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the users.

—And the users, yes, the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is quite right. This is the other thing that has not been focused upon enough in recent years, it is not just the providers of services, it is also consumers. There are some people who have a great capacity and great enthusiasm for visiting doctors and consuming as many services as they possibly can.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment at least, most are having services provided in an environment where they have a credit card fully underwritten by the government that they can use as often as they like, whenever they like. Unfortunately, in the health care system, consumers are not always in a position to make an informed decision about whether they need the service. I am a medical practitioner myself, but if a neurosurgeon tells me I need something done in my brain stem, I am hardly in a position to say that I do not need it.

The bill also seeks to streamline administration of approvals for approved pathology practitioners and approved pathology authorities. This amendment is really going to allow the backdating of approvals in limited circumstances to make sure that Medicare benefits are not being disrupted when it is not really warranted.

We have had instances where some pathology providers have got their paperwork in a week or two weeks beyond the due date and then both they and the patients who received the services suffered because the Medicare benefits had not been made payable.

The application must be no more than a month late. It must serve the public interest and late application must be for trivial inadvertence or something that is beyond the control of the pathology practice. Obviously, the government is not trying to encourage laziness in this regard.

The measures that we are introducing in the bill are important also to the maintenance of the pathology agreement that was introduced in the 1996‐97 budget and which limits pathology expenditure under Medicare to predetermined levels. The arrangements that were made last year in relation to the pathology agreement are really unprecedented in the history of relations between the medical profession and the Commonwealth government. This 1996‐97 budget measure heralded a new era, not only for pathology, but perhaps also for other sections of the medical profession. To a limited extent, in last year's budget, radiology providers also entered into such arrangements.

For the first time in the history of the Medicare benefits schedule, a negotiation was concluded with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia and the Commonwealth to cap, or limit, the total expenditure for pathology to predetermined amounts for a three‐year period. If expenditure, over the three years, is below the six per cent agreed annual growth in outlays, then there is an increase in the Medicare benefits schedule fee for pathology the following year and if expenditure is above the six per cent growth, then there is going to be a commensurate reduction the following year.

I think great credit should be given to the maturity of the pathology providers and that section of the profession for entering into such an arrangement. I well recall in 1993 suggesting to general practitioners with then $2.2 billion in Medicare outlays in general practice that we ought to be doing something like that there. All I can say is I had to start sleeping on my side with the one or two knives I had in between my shoulder blades. I take my hat off to the pathologists for concluding these sorts of negotiations.

The measures that we are introducing in the Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997 really supplement or help to maintain the integrity and the importance of those arrangements which all of us want to see succeed. If that pathology deal does not succeed then we are all in trouble, as government, as pathology providers, as taxpayers and indeed as patients.

The bill also tries to eliminate inappropriate practices within sections of the industry which have the potential to undermine, as I say, not only that landmark agreement, but confidence in the discipline of pathology generally.

Coming back to the remarks of the member for Calwell, it has annoyed me over the years that people have usually been quite happy to pay the surgeon's fee, a little less happy to pay the anaesthetist's fee—even though there is no greater faith you can have in somebody than to have a general anaesthetic—but they always whinge about paying the pathologist's bill. They always whinge about it. It is not until you have someone misdiagnose your pap smear or until you have somebody tell you that your wife's breast lump is nothing to worry about and it turns out three months later to be a missed malignancy thanks to poor histology that you realise the value of a pathology service and a pathology service provided well. This bill will play a role in helping to maintain confidence in the discipline of pathology itself.

Again, I would like to pay tribute to the Australian Association of Pathology Practices for the support that they have given to the bill. I know they have played a role in putting the bill together. They also make the point that one of the stupid aspects of the current legislation is that the Health Insurance Commission only has the power to go into licensed collection centres. It does not have the power to go into unlicensed collection centres. It is a bit like saying to the police, `You can raid a licensed brothel, but you can't raid one which is not.' I realise that is probably an unfortunate analogy, but it is the kind of stupidity with which we have been trying to deal. The commission has got, as I say, no power to enter unlicensed premises.

The display of a licence number or advice concerning a licence on the outside of the premises would at least let the commission know what sort of collection facility they are dealing with. The pathology providers themselves are only too happy to do anything they can to try to deal with those within their discipline who are bringing a bad name to the profession and the industry itself.

In its recent report on medifraud and inappropriate practice, the Australian National Audit Office noted attempts by some pathologists and a few radiologists to enter into kickback arrangements and indicated its concern that unnecessary services may be ordered by GPs in return for benefits from service providers or pathologists. This bill is much more likely to ensure that, where premises are occupied by an approved pathology provider, the provider must personally use them to render those professional services.

In conclusion, it will never be possible to devise a system which will not be the subject of exploitation by some providers or indeed some consumers. The medical profession, by definition, is a group of people who are reasonably intelligent and hardworking. Unfortunately, if they go off the rails and decide to misdirect their energies, they can be extremely good at getting around any kind of system.

I also make the point—and I realise that I am lengthening my period of service on the backbench every time I speak—that, eventually Australia will have to reach the point where we realise that we are running a system which lends itself to abuse. No matter how hard we try to improve the legislation—and this legislation will be an improvement—the system will continue to be open to abuse by all kinds of people. Perhaps, in a decade or so from now, people will look back on what I and others have said in this regard and say, `Just maybe they were right'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill is about improving the efficiency of Medicare by bettering the contributions to health care by Australian pathology services. As the honourable member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) has mentioned, it is the product of negotiations between the coalition, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset and in his regrettable absence, I wish to congratulate the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) on the consultative approach he has seemingly adopted in putting together this bill. The coalition went to the last election with a promise of being more inclusive, open and consultative than the then government. And yet, as I will make clear, during the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 debate, the alarm bells have been ringing amongst professional and industry groups about the government's apparent disregard for independent, expert opinion on policy.

It is pleasing to note that such a criticism does not appear to be justified in this instance. I have had feedback on this legislation from three pathology practices which operate in my electorate. Each of them indicated their general agreement with the changes proposed in this bill and have noted the importance of the two national pathology organisations being involved in the decision making process.

One of the intended consequences of the bill is a bolstering of the powers of the authority of the Health Insurance Commission, the HIC, in its battle against overservicing. The Health Insurance Commission's 1995‐96 annual report makes it clear that one of its key functions is to detect, investigate and prevent inappropriate practice by service providers. This includes the services provided by pathologists.

The government has expressed concern at the unlawful or unethical arrangements between some medical practitioners and pathologists that encourage the commission of pathology services where they are not really required. It has good reason to be concerned, Mr Deputy Speaker, because the practice of overservicing could become a major problem for the Medicare scheme. The government is anticipating that the measures contained in this legislation will cap the growth outlays on pathology services at six per cent a year, coincidentally the same as the provisional tax uplift factor—just an unhappy coincidence.
However, it gives no indication of the potential savings in its financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum, except to say that the bill will:
. . . reduce the level of inappropriate pathology activity that imposes costs on the government.
The Australian National Audit Office, the ANAO, produced a report into inappropriate medical practice in 1996‐97. It noted that:
An organisation should have an estimate of at least the order of magnitude of the leakage of funds it manages, in order to decide whether its response is proportionate to the problem.

Official figures show that the HIC had recovered—or was in the process of recovering—more than $1 million of Medicare benefits which had been paid incorrectly to service providers and patients in the year 1995‐96. However, this figure severely under‐represents the true cost to revenue of Medicare fraud in this context.

The 1996‐97 Auditor General's report on the Health Insurance Commission revealed that an estimated $135 million was lost in sham claims by medical practitioners and Medicare card holders in the year 1994‐95. Even more alarming than this figure was the comment by the ANAO that:
The small sample used to derive these estimates means that it is possible that the leakage could be up to three times higher than estimated.

On that supposition from the ANAO, it is possible that Medicare fraud could have amounted to more than $400 million in one year. It is little wonder that our public health system promises to fall apart at the seams.

While these figures are only estimates, the ANAO report stated that the Health Insurance Commission had agreed to consider releasing a report into Medicare fraud in this year of 1997. That will allow it to draw on three years of data and offer a more accurate assessment of this risk. The audit office supported such a move, saying that:

BREAK.PARA: The knowledge of the magnitude or value of leakage is important both for management purposes and for accountability.
It went on to note that:
Publication of these estimates will assist the commission in its education role, and encourage greater attention amongst all stakeholders, to the importance of antifraud action.

Two parties were identified as being the `primary beneficiaries' of appropriate medical practice. They include health consumers `who then receive the most suitable medical treatment', and the government, `if savings can be identified from inappropriately high levels of service'. To my knowledge, the Health Insurance Commission has yet to produce any such document. I wonder whether the Minister for Health and Family Services, had he been here seeing his legislation through the parliament, could advise us of any state of play on this point.

It must be acknowledged that it is difficult to quantify overservicing in pathology services in the figures I have mentioned. However, it is clear that the government must take decisive action if it is to combat Medicare fraud of any persuasion. As I mentioned, the government aims to cap growth in outlays on pathology at six per cent per annum. Anecdotal evidence from the United States of America suggests that the concept of capping may actually exacerbate the problem of ballooning costs in the health industries.

In the October‐November 1996 edition of Healthcover, it was noted that volume performance standards—that is, where a target rate is set for a year and future annual updates are measured against this figure—have increased the cost to the American equivalent of Medicare. That journal noted:
The problem is that a single crude target does not have very strong incentives for individual physicians to change their behaviour.
It went on to say that:

In fact, it may have some perverse incentives, because they say, `Well, the volume is going up by all those other guys and if I am going to maintain my income, I am going to have to increase my volume, because I know the next year it is going to be offset'.
I am interested to learn whether this concern was noted by the Minister for Health and Family Services when the decision to cap pathology costs was made.

This bill is not, nor does it pretend to be, the answer to all of Medicare's ills. It is just one part of what must be a comprehensive overhaul of our public health system if we are to avoid its total, or something approaching total, collapse.

In the year ending June 1996 a staggering 196 million Medicare services, including those for pathology services, were processed by the Health Insurance Commission—196 million in a year. The most recent census figures put Australia's resident population at approximately 18.3 million. A quick crunching of figures indicates that this equates to the provision of around nine medical services to every Australian man, woman and child in a year. That is getting well on the way to one visit to a medical practitioner a month, statistically. Of course, the reality is that most people do not visit a medical practitioner anywhere near this often. On the flip side, there are those who visit their GP and other practitioners more often than they go to their hairdresser or barber.

As I noted in a previous debate, the recent Productivity Commission report into private health insurance asserted that the demand side of the Medicare equation was in dire need of modification. These figures certainly give added weight to any such claim. The report stated very clearly that a lacklustre attitude towards our universal health care system now pervades the Australian community. As a general rule, we simply do not appreciate the true cost of the services made available to us through the so‐called `free' Medicare system.

Most medical professionals do not condone overservicing, of course. Indeed, the 1996‐97 Auditor‐General's performance audit of the Health Insurance Commission found that most fraud detected by the HIC came from `complaints by the public or by members of the medical and pharmaceutical professions' who refused to condone what they saw as improper behaviour. Those pathologists who do practice ethically should not be concerned with the government's move to ensure that a notice identifying them as licensed pathologists is to remain visible on their premises. The Australian National Audit Office identified prevention of inappropriate practice as a key role of the HIC. By ensuring that licences identifying registered pathology centres are more visible, the Health Insurance Commission should become more pro‐active in preventing overservicing.

In a buyer beware market, new subsection 23DNK(1) of the act will offer a greater level of protection to the consumer. Patients can still opt to have tests done at non‐licensed pathology centres, but they will not be eligible for a Medicare rebate on those services. That is entirely reasonable.

The current penalty for non‐compliance by a pathology centre is a mere $100 fine. This amendment seeks to increase the penalty to $1,000. In the scheme of things, this figure represents a mild penalty, considering that an individual's health may be put at risk if tests are conducted in an environment that fails to meet good Australian pathology standards. However, a $1,000 fine will certainly be a greater deterrent to opportunistic practitioners than the current $100.

Item 13 of the bill amends section 133 of the principal act and will allow the HIC to prescribe certain penalties for minor offences. As with the changes to licensing, that will not detrimentally affect reputable pathologists. Rather, the government claims it will allow for more rapid and less expensive disciplining of minor pathology violations.

Evidence suggests that speedy action on the part of the HIC can lead to a reduction in inappropriate practice. For example, the Health Insurance Commission recently produced a report that suggested that where they had acted to caution practitioners suspected of inappropriate practice, they made savings of $40,000 of Medicare expenditure per intervention in the first year of counselling. The HIC extrapolated this figure to calculate that they may currently be achieving `savings of up to $19 million per year through counselling, through reduced expenditure which would have otherwise occurred.' If that figure is accurate, it represents—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the advisers in the chamber wish to conduct extended conversations they should leave the chamber. The honourable member for Curtin.

—As I was saying, if that figure is accurate, it represents a very significant saving to revenue indeed. Information like that should be made available to the general medical community, if it is not already, to further encourage appropriate practices. But I understand that that does not occur. The Auditor‐General's report stated:

BREAK.PARA: The annual report—
that is, the Health Insurance Commission's annual report—
does not contain any indication of the magnitude of leakage through fraud or the magnitude of inappropriate practice and the savings achieved through counselling.

It was further noted that the 1995‐96 portfolio budget statement for Human Services and Health contained scant information on the cost to the community of inappropriate practice. This is also the case with the two subsequent budgets that were handed down by the present government. Surely if this information is at hand, it should be published widely to communicate the very real, and maybe ever growing, problems that plague Medicare.

The government is right to tighten up the provisions relating to `act of grace' payments where pathology organisations fail to have their licence renewed. The explanatory memorandum notes that there may be occasions where pathology centres fail to submit the necessary application and fee for the renewal of their licence because of circumstances beyond their control. This may be the case, but in the interests of maintaining uniform standards in pathology services this should be the exception and not the norm.

Just as every other business is required to meet compliance cost obligations or face the consequences, so too should those in the field of pathology. Pathologists are aware of the onus to renew their licence on an annual basis and should therefore include a little forward planning in their calendars to prepare for that eventuality. Further, the Health Insurance Commission already alerts applicants whose licences are about to expire that they need to renew them immediately. The amendments in this bill will still allow for act of grace payments to be made to pathologists in certain circumstances, but it will now be the responsibility of the minister to authorise such payments. It is to be hoped that this will see a reduction in the costly and burdensome process involved with the backdating of Medicare benefits to the service provider.

Importantly, this bill also contains a provision that will protect the rights of pathologists who are not granted act of grace payments by the minister. Item 11 in the bill stipulates that any person who unsuccessfully appeals to the minister for a review of a decision to not backdate an approval may put their case to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

It is important that this bill be passed in order to maintain the integrity of our Medicare system. As I have outlined in earlier debates, overservicing is not common to the majority of medical practitioners. Only a fraction of professionals have come under the scrutiny of the Professional Service Review Scheme in the past. One would hope that by upping the penalties this figure will decline even further and any future growth will be headed off.

It is also crucial that the Health Insurance Commission utilises the additional powers it will gain once this legislation is proclaimed. Professional bodies, including the Australian Association of Pathology Practices and the Royal College of Pathologists, reportedly share concern that the professional review division of the HIC is not as active in pursuing Medicare fraud as it should be. It is incumbent on the Health Insurance Commission to allay these fears by actively and indiscriminately identifying offenders.

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to sum up the debate and thank honourable members for their contribution. The Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997 underlies the government commitment to work where possible with the medical profession to improve outcomes for providers and consumers. It has been a pleasure working with pathologists over the last two years. I wish all the different groups within the medical profession were as willing to take a long‐term view and as willing to see the government's concerns as well as their own.

BREAK.PARA: Last year, we signed a historic agreement with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices and the Royal College of Pathologists in Australia to cap the expenditure under the Medicare benefits arrangements to predetermined amounts. This is the first time under Medicare that such a comprehensive agreement has been established and it does highlight, I think, an area where the government has been able to work with the profession, where previous governments have not been able to.
The first year of this agreement recently concluded had growth rates in pathology benefits significantly down on the previous two years and the bill today strengthens these agreements.

The proposed amendments of the bill will streamline pathology administrative arrangements and strengthen the power of the Health Insurance Commission to enforce the provisions of the Health Insurance Act relating to pathology.
The proposals to strengthen the power of the Health Insurance Commission were developed in consultation with peak pathology professional bodies and have their support.
I am pleased to acknowledge the support of the opposition for this bill and I commend the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 11 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) written and (b) other expressions of concern about the safe operation of air services did his Department or any other agency for which he is responsible receive in December 1996.
(2) What was the specific nature of each of the expressions referred to in part (1), categorised by type of aircraft service.
(3) Which of the expressions referred to in part (1) originated from passengers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Responses on written reports and other expressions of concern about the safe operation of air services in December 1996 have been provided by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI), the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) and Airservices Australia. In the same period, the Department of Transport and Regional Development received no written reports or other expressions of concern about the safe operation of air services.

(1) (a) In December 1996, BASI received a total of five written reports via its Confidential Aviation Incident Reporting system; CASA received 6 written expressions of concern; and Airservices received 128 written reports of concern.
(b) In December 1996, BASI received no other expressions of concern but CASA received 5 oral expressions of concern.
Airservices does not maintain a record of other/oral expressions of concern because it is an Airservices requirement that all concerns regarding safety of operations are to be in writing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 12 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he written to the major petrol companies asking them to consider access to their terminal facilities; if so, what response has he received.

(2) In his negotiations with the petrol companies has he pursued terminal access involving (a) physical access at prices, terms and conditions set by the terminal owner, (b) a downstream legal right to obtain product at commercially negotiated prices, terms and conditions that may be subject to ACCC analysis and determination or (c) any other access regime.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to comments by the Minister for Science and Technology on 16 December 1996 that the Minister expected Shell, BP and Mobil to open their petrol terminals for access in a matter of weeks; if so, (a) does he share this expectation and (b) how has it been met.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 11 December 1996 the Government announced its decision to deregulate wholesale petrol prices in 1997 subject to the resolution of a number of outstanding issues, including terminal access and horizontal arrangements in the industry. I wrote to each of the major oil companies about this matter on 23 December 1996 noting, among other things, that the Government would be seeking commitments from the oil majors that they would provide open access to their oil terminals. Responses have been received from each of the major oil companies.

(2)(a), (b) and (c) The Government has pursued terminal access on the basis of physical access to terminals and product. This will help to establish a competitive wholesale market with persons able to seek wholesale petrol from several outlets. Competition will discipline prices as in any other competitive market.
(3) My attention had not been drawn to the comments attributed to the Minister for Science and Technology.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Securities Commission Investigators: Individual Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to part (2) of question No.920 (Hansard, 27 February 1997, page 1471), (a) does an Australian Securities Commission (ASC) investigator have express power of entry only when a warrant has been issued and (b) are all individuals interviewed by an ASC investigator informed of this.

(2) Further to his answer to part (3) of question No. 920 concerning an alteration of the name of an addressee on a form, (a) which section of the Act permits this alteration and (b) was the form referred to a legal document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1a) An Australian Securities Commission (ASC) investigator has express power of entry only when a warrant has been issued.

(1b) I am advised by the ASC that it does not necessarily notify every individual interviewed in connection with an inquiry or investigation that it has the power, for example, to apply to a magistrate for a search warrant pursuant to subsection 35(1) of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 (the ASC Law). Every investigation turns on its facts and recourse to compulsory powers may not be required. I am advised that search warrants, in particular, are rarely necessary.

(2a) An ASC investigator, duly delegated by the Commission, is authorised to determine when a notice under section 30 of the ASC Law is required during the course of an investigation. The investigator is required to include information in the notice in accordance with the prescribed form, being Form 2, Regulation 5 of the Australian Securities Commission Regulations (ASC Regulations). The investigator, as a delegate of the ASC, may amend the content of the notice he or she has prepared where, prior to service of the notice, circumstances change, for example, the company officer identified in the notice is on holiday. The notice is not a judicial notice (a warrant, for example, is a judicial notice). It is issued by an ASC investigator who holds a delegation to exercise this power.
(2b) The form and content of the notice referred to is prescribed by Form 2, Regulation 5 of the ASC Regulations, and is part of the ASC Law.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether Cambridge Gulf Exploration provided information of a ramp of their shares where directors of County Natwest accumulated over 20% of the issued stock in Cambridge Gulf Exploration from October 1993 to January 1994 and sold it to one client, Jardine Fleming of Hong Kong, and that this led to two directors being asked to leave by an executive sent from the London office of Natwest Securities.

(2) Is he able to say whether Mr B. Conroy of Cambridge Gulf Exploration provided evidence to the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) that showed that secret commissions were sought by a current director on behalf of ex‐directors of County Natwest during the share placement.

(3) Was the information referred to in parts (1) and (2), and other information relevant to County Natwest and Jardine Fleming, provided to the ASC, including the dismissal of the participants and compensation of $25m being paid by Jardine Fleming.
(4) Did the ASC conclude after more than a month of studying the information that an investigation into County Natwest past and present officials was warranted and wrote to that effect.
(5) Did the ASC agree to provide Mr Conway or his solicitors with information relevant to the matter; if so, has it done so; if not, why not.
(6) Is Mr Conway the only person in this matter before the courts; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Cambridge Gulf Exploration (CGE), through its solicitors Bennett & Co, wrote to the ASC alleging that trading in shares and options in CGE had been manipulated. I am not in a position to comment on the reasons why directors may have left County Natwest.

(2) While the ASC has been provided with information, either directly by Mr Conway or by Bennett & Co (which, the ASC believes, was acting for CGE at the time), I am advised that the ASC did not consider that any information provided to it was evidence relating to secret commissions which could be used in court.
(3) The information referred to in parts (1) and (2) and other information was provided to the ASC.

(4) The ASC advised Bennett & Co that the ASC would be investigating matters raised in their letter of complaint referred to in part (1). These matters were connected to past trading in the shares and options of CGE.

(5) A letter informing CGE of the ASC's conclusions following its investigations has been sent to CGE. Bennett & Co, who sent the original letter of complaint to the ASC on behalf of CGE, advised the ASC to write directly to the company. As Mr Conway is no longer a director of CGE, it is not appropriate for the ASC to inform him of the outcome of CGE's complaint.

(6) Mr Conway and Mr Malcolm Macleod are before the courts on charges related to statements made in CGE releases to the ASX in December 1993. Both men, following a preliminary hearing, have been committed for trial in the District Court of Western Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government undertaken a noise audit to examine the impact of aircraft noise on residents in suburbs surrounding Perth Airport, especially those in South Guildford; if so, when and what were the audit findings; if an audit has not been undertaken, will he initiate an audit.
(2) Will the Government institute a noise compensation regime to Perth Airport prior to the privatisation of Perth Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The Government has not undertaken a noise audit to examine the impact of aircraft noise on residents in suburbs surrounding Perth Airport and has no plans at this time to conduct such an audit.

However, a review of noise abatement procedures in use at Perth Airport was carried out by Airservices Australia late last year. The review found that the noise abatement procedures were adequate and that changes to flight paths proposed for introduction on 5 December 1996 were expected to produce favourable environmental outcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

(2) For each category referred to in part (1), how many took off using the north‐south runways, and how many using those runways took off to the north.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Accurate data is not available for September 1995.
(1) (a) For the six month period from 1 October 1995 to 1 April 1996, 65,962 aircraft took off from Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
(b) For the six month period from 1 October 1996 to 1 April 1997, 66,857 aircraft took off from Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
(2) The number of take offs on the north‐south runway for the period 1 October 1995 to 1 April 1996 was 65,131. Of these, 20,266 were departures to the north on Runway 34 Left.

The number of take offs on the north‐south runways for the period 1 October 1996 to 1 April 1997 was 60,448. Of these, 11,433 were departures to the north on Runway 34 Left. There were 8,070 departures to the north on Runway 34 Right which turned to the east soon after take‐off.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 May 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Would the development of a regional airport away from the Sydney Basin reduce the impact on population constraints around Sydney and open for expansion a regional area close to Sydney.

(2) Is Goulburn more attractive to airport development, compared to the alternatives of Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy and would it be the least costly in initial land acquisition and transport development between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne.

(3) Would an airport at Goulburn (a) be more attractive to the residents of Sydney and (b) have a greater overall benefit to the Australian people than development within an already overcrowded metropolitan region.

(4) Would the construction impact of developing a complex near Goulburn (a) provide relief and development to regional Australia and (b) be reflected in reduced user charges thereby making Australian business more competitive.
(5) What are the major problems associated with the placement of an international airport away from Sydney.

(6) Is the building of an airport midway between Sydney and Canberra, linked to a very fast train system and providing an integrated freight and transport facility hub, worthy of initial investigation and in keeping with international trends for airport development away from major residential areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Possible sites for the second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek and the Holsworthy Military Reserve are being examined in the EIS process.
Major airports recently built or currently being built at major cities overseas are generally located no more than 50 kilometres from the central business district.

There are major disadvantages with Goulburn and other remote locations. The distance from Sydney has major adverse implications for travel times, convenience, cost and connection with Sydney's existing airport. As a consequence, there would be a strong likelihood that passengers and airlines would be unwilling to use the second airport thereby further increasing the pressures on Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. The increased costs of providing suitable road and rail access and linkages to other support services (such as a fuel line) would also be significant. For these reasons the Government is not considering possible sites outside the Sydney Basin for the second major Sydney airport.
(2) See answer to (1).

The Commonwealth owns the Holsworthy Military Reserve and the existing Badgerys Creek airport site. Two of the airport design options under consideration at Badgerys Creek would require additional land to be acquired.
(3), (4), (5) and (6) See answer to (1).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 26 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether United Energy decided to abolish its user pays power surge insurance scheme following advice from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).
(2) Was the ACCC of the opinion that the United Energy scheme was in breach of the Trade Practices Act.
(3) Has the ACCC advised other power distribution companies in Victoria on the legality of power surge schemes.
(4) Does he support the ACCC on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 22 April 1997, United Energy announced the introduction of its United Energy Surge Plan, which aims to provide residential consumers with `no‐cost' protection against damage caused by power surges. Two other Victorian electricity distribution companies offer `no cost' surge cover for residential customers.

The ACCC has informed me that United Energy's announcement followed discussions the Commission held with the Electricity Supply Association of Australia, several Victorian electricity distribution companies, the Victorian Regulator‐General and the Electricity Industry Ombudsman on the question of who bears liability for damage caused by poor quality of supply of electricity. Poor quality supply includes power surges and `brownouts'.

The ACCC initiated these discussions following its investigations into a number of Victorian electricity distribution companies' offers of insurance products to consumers. These products were expressed to cover damage caused by poor quality supply of electricity where it was not the fault of the electricity company itself. The ACCC was concerned that information provided to consumers should not lead to any misunderstandings by them as to the full extent of their statutory rights under the Trade Practices Act. (See below.)

(2) The ACCC has informed me that at no time did it express a view that United Energy was in breach of the Trade Practices Act. Rather the Commission expressed the view that, while it does not object to the provision of insurance schemes or related products in themselves, it has concerns that the information provided by electricity companies about such products should not lead to misunderstandings by consumers, either by express or implied representation, as to the full extent of their statutory rights under Part V Division 2 of the Act. In the Commission's view, these rights include an entitlement by consumers to be compensated for damage caused by unmerchantable quality electricity irrespective of whether the supplier is negligent or not.

As a consequence, the ACCC informed the electricity distribution companies that they might have to fully refund fees paid by consumers for protection plans which did no more than offer consumers what was already a statutory right. United Energy advised the ACCC that it would fully refund payments made by its customers for the previous PowerGuard Plan.

(3) The ACCC has written to electricity companies and regulators across Australia concerning the promotion of insurance schemes and the implied rights of consumers under Part V Division 2 of the Trade Practices Act. Such insurance schemes must be conveyed as additional to, and not in place of, all other statutory rights.

(4) The ACCC is an independent statutory authority with responsibility, among other things, for administering the Trade Practices Act. The Government supports the efforts of the Commission in seeking to ensure that market conduct across the economy is consistent with the provisions of the Act and that consumers are safeguarded in their dealings with producers and sellers. The Government is also mindful that protection of the rights of consumers needs to be balanced against the costs this may impose on producers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 17 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was evidence of increased traffic presented to him prior to his decision to keep Essendon Airport open; if so (a) what evidence, (b) over what period was the evidence collected and (c) did his office seek to verify the evidence.
(2) Has his office investigated claims made in questions Nos. 1362, 1666 and 1667 concerning the increased practice of "touch and go" procedures at the airport; if not, why not.
(3) Will the control of Essendon Airport be transferred to the private sector; if so (a) how and (b) when.
(4) Will all government subsidies and contingent liabilities to the airport cease once it is handed over to the private sector.
(5) Does he have contingency plans should a private sector operator to take over Essendon Airport not be found.
(6) Will existing Federal Airport Corporation functions at the airport continue to be performed under private sector operators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) & (b) Data from Airservices Australia on movements at Essendon Airport have been provided on a regular basis. This data shows that for the year to date aircraft movements at Essendon Airport have increased. The total movements for the year 1995‐96 was 61,030. Between 1 July 1996 to 30 April 1997 there have been 57,634 movements.

(c) In January 1997, media speculation about a large increase in the number of movements at Essendon Airport caused the Department of Transport and Regional Development to seek a complete analysis of monthly movement data at the airport for the 1995 and 1996 calender years. The analysis revealed that while there was an increase in movements at Essendon Airport, these increases could not be considered as substantial as reported in the media. The monthly statistics for 1 January to 30 May 1997 show that movements are continuing to increase.
The FAC advised that this increase can be attributed to growth across all users of the airport.

(2) Investigations into the claims made in previous questions concerning an increase in the numbers of "touch and go" movements revealed that separate statistics for "touch and go" movements are not kept by Airservices Australia. However, Airservices Australia estimates that there are on average about 10 "touch and go" movements per week including circuit operations and aircraft transiting Essendon from another airport.

(3) Following the successful sale of long term leases for the operation of Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth Airports, the Government announced that it is offering a further 15 Federal airports for simultaneous trade sale. Essendon Airport is one of the airports that will be offered for sale.

Expressions of interest in the 15 airports are expected to be sought around September/October 1997, following completion of Commonwealth due diligence and other sales preparatory work. Disposal of all 15 airports is expected to be completed by 30 June 1998.

(4) A full evaluation of these and other issues will be conducted as part of the Government Sales Team's due diligence process which will precede the formal tender process for Essendon Airport. In light of these findings, appropriate decisions in relation to the issues will be taken at that time.

(5) The Government is committed to the sale of all Phase 2 airports. Decisions on the future ownership of Essendon Airport will be made in the context of a full evaluation of indicative and binding bids received from potential bidders.

(6) A private owner of Essendon Airport will continue to operate the airport consistent with its obligations under the sale agreement, legislative requirements, and commercial decisions. Regulatory functions currently undertaken by the FAC will be transferred to relevant Commonwealth and State agencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is an allied ex‐serviceman who has lived in Australia for 50 years and who now is an Australian citizen entitled to repatriation benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.
(2) Is the ex‐serviceman referred to in part (1) entitled to a service pension from the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 does not provide for Repatriation benefits in the form of disability pension and treatment for war‐caused injury and disease in respect of allied ex‐servicemen (or ex‐servicewomen). However, under the legislation, a service pension may be paid to an allied veteran.
(2) An allied ex‐serviceman (or ex‐servicewoman) who has been an Australian resident for at least 10 years may be entitled to a service pension, if the person:
‐ has been a member of the defence force established by an allied country; and
‐ served during a period of hostilities; and

‐ rendered in connection with a war or war‐like operation, in which the Defence Forces of Australia were engaged, service in an area within or outside the country in which the person enlisted in those forces, being service in respect of which the person incurred danger from hostile forces of the enemy.
The residency requirement does not apply to a refugee who holds a permanent entry visa and is a permanent resident in Australia.
An allied veteran may be entitled to the service pension on the grounds of age if the veteran is male and aged 60 years or older, or is female and aged 56 years or older.
Younger allied veterans may be entitled to service pension on the grounds of invalidity if they are permanently incapacitated for work.
It should be noted that citizenship, or a period of residence longer than 10 years, has no effect on the eligibility of an allied veteran for service pension.
Both types of service pension (age and invalidity) are subject to the income and assets tests. However, these tests do not apply to "blinded" veterans.
The eligibility criteria for service pension requires that, for a person to be entitled to this pension, he or she must not have served at any time in an enemy force.
